text:
I've made this 8 times now. The first 7 times, I skipped the Parmesan, thinking it would not make that much of a difference. Boy, was I wrong! Last night I added the Parmesan, and it took this dish from good to excellent. Don't skip the Parmesan! I  also use butter instead of olive oil; it gives the dish a richer taste. This is a wonderful recipe for everyday or company, and the best part is you always have the ingredients on hand.

text:
Applauds to Carol.The BEST chicken breast ever. I am not a enthusiastic chicken lover and I find it difficult to find a good moist chicken breast recipe with flavor. The recipe calls for 2 tsp.of garlic crushed(not 2 cloves).This could be why everyone says to double up on garlic because they are counting cloves instead of teaspoons of garlic. I used 7 BIG cloves of garlic and upped the oil 1/4c and bread crumbs, Cheese combo 1/4c for 6 breast. Baked for 30 min. Per--fect. This is not fried/baked chicken. This is a Exquisite dish and the aroma is Heavenly. IF there are left over,place on a salad for a nice lunch.  Encore

text:
We've made basically the same recipe for years using low or no-fat italian dressing instead of the olive oil.  Just as tasty and a LOT less fat.  No real recipe required - just dip chicken in dressing then dredge in a mixture of equal parts crumbs and parmesan, seasoned with additional garlic and herbs if you'd like.  To me, this was just much too greasy.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was super easy.  The chicken has a very nice garlic smell while cooking.  The taste is mild and not over powering.  If you are looking for a strong garlic taste this is not it.  However, since I was cooking for a one year old and a picky husband the taste was perfect.  
The recipe is super fast, taking only a few minutes to warm the oil and roll the chicken in the coating.  
The only thing I did wrong was using chicken breast tenders rather than chicken breasts.  I don't recommend this.  You have to decrease the cooking time to prevent the chicken from drying out and the coating does not get crispy.  The chicken was just starting to get crispy when I had to remove it from the oven.  I think it would have been even better if I had been able to cook it at least another 15 minutes.  
I will make it again using whole chicken breasts in the future.

text:
Pretty yummy! Very easy. The chicken was tender and had a nice flavor. I asked my husband if it was a keeper and he said "Oh yeah!" The only thing is I bought the real parmesan cheese still in shredded form and couldn't figure how the cheese and bread crumbs were going to stick to the chicken! My husband said,"I think you're supposed to use the powdered stuff in the green can." Oopps. That makes sense. Make sure you start off with the stuff in the green can. You know that stuff you put on spaghetti!

text:
WOW! Delicious with little effort!  I changed this: I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs because they are RELIABLY more moist then breasts (always trim off any extra fat with kitchen sheers). I ran the garlic and olive oil through my mini-blender so it was like a smooth garlic emulsion oil (I did warm the oil in the microwave as suggested).  I tossed 1/2 the chicken into a ziplock, poured in the garlic oil....tossed in the other half of the chicken and closed the bag.  I hand squished the garlic oil all throughout the chicken by kneading the bag. That saves the messy step of hand dipping each piece into the oil and then into the crumbs.  I used Italian bread crumbs with the grated cheese and coated the pieces as suggested.  It was excellent!!.  It really was very easy, tasty and light!! Baked 400Â° for 23 minutes.

text:
For those who prefer a stronger garlic flavour instead of olive oil substitute garlic oil or make your own by adding 2 Tbs chopped garlic to 1 cup olive or canola oil,let stand for 24 hrs in fridge and use within a week.  Add GRANULATED garlic powder to the crumb mixture, use Romano cheese instead of Parmesan for a more distinct flavour.

text:
I first made this recipe several months ago when I was scrambling last minute to find something to make for dinner.  I always have garlic, bread crumbs, olive oil, and parmesan cheese on hand, so this recipe was perfect, and was absolutely delicious!   After perusing all the reviews, I followed some tips and upped the crumbs & cheese.  Since we loooove garlic, I used more of that too (3 large cloves worth).   I also used Italian Seasoned bread crumbs and like others have mentioned, the cooking time was more like 25-30 minutes, not 30-35.... I've since made it several more times, and now I regularly use even more garlic (about 4 cloves), 1/3 cup olive oil, 1/2 cup bread crumbs (half Panko crumbs and half Italian), and 1/2 cup parmesan.   I made it at a dinner party for 12 and it was a huge hit.   It's so moist and flavorful, even my hard-to-please father-in-law who doesn't usually like chicken breasts (he prefers dark meat chicken) raved about it!

text:
Taking advice of others, b/c we love garlic, I used 5 cloves of garlic and the seasoned bread crumbs. I also added 1/4 stick of butter to baking dish. When chicken was cooked, I poured juices into small saute pan and added 1 TBL of cornstarch mixed with 1/4 cup water. Then added some Half and Half and heated, stirring until thickened. Once thickened, I added some parmesan cheese. This made a wonderful creamy sauce to pour over chicken. I served with garlic mashed potatoes. YUM!!!

text:
Definitely add the parmesan cheese during the last five minutes of cooking. I also added salt, pepper, parsley, and garlic powder to the bread crumbs. Pretty good overall.

*Note....I made this recipe again, and I used the parmesan in the can instead of fresh (which should have been specified)....it was much better with the cheese in the can mixed with the breadcrumb coating and the fresh parmesan added the last five minutes of baking...This was wonderful this way! I also added extra garlic the second time around.

text:
Wow, this was so good!!  I used Italian seasoned bread crumbs with a little black pepper added in.  I only made 2 chicken pieces (not 4) but i did not cut the recipe in half.  There still seemed to be just the right amount of oil/garlic and crumbs.  I also used 5 large garlic cloves, so I used way more garlic than was called for.  Any remaining oil/garlic was drizzled over chicken right before baking.  I would definitely recommend 5 cloves per 2 chicken breasts, it turned out very flavorful but not overpowering.  Absolutely wonderful chicken!

text:
The reason I did not give this 5 stars is because the first time I made this, I followed the recipe exactly and didn't find it to be anything special. The second time, I added some fresh rosemary to the garlic mixture, some ground pepper and about a tablespoon of Italian seasoning to the breadcrumbs, pounded the chicken breasts a little thinner and turned the breasts once halfway through baking. When I did that, it was perfect. 25 minutes baking time was plenty, if I'd kept it in any longer it would have overbrowned. This dish is also very versatile. I have served this with cheese sauce, spaghetti sauce, rice, stuffing, mashed potatoes, pasta--just about anything goes well with it. This is also one of the easiest recipes I have ever made, and I always have the ingredients on hand. I don't think I will ever make breaded chicken any other way again. Thanks, Carol, for this super-easy recipe!

text:
I've always made this with butter, but can't wait to try it with garlic-infused oil. However, I think 425 is way too hot. I've always baked the chicken for 35-45 minutes at 350 and it comes out evenly cooked and juicy.

I've also used herb-seasoned stuffing mix instead of the breadcrumbs. You just have to crush it in a food processor first.

text:
We call this oven fried chicken and just love it. This is a great dish to play around with. Try Panko bread crumbs, or crushed corn flakes for something different. (Use your imagination here, some folks even use crushed pretzels and love it!) You can also sub mayo or melted butter for the olive oil, but you'll get more health benefits from olive oil. You can also vary the herbs in your breading. this is just a fun, delicious, juicy and tender dish, no matter how you go!

text:
YUM!!!!  Soooooooooo good!  The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars is because I had to make a couple modifications.  The recipe as written is 4 stars, but it is 5 stars if you do this:  double the garlic (at least!).  You can't even taste the garlic unless you use at least 2x the amount.  Also, if you pound the breasts thin and then broil them instead of bake them, they will be crispy and golden on both sides, and moist and juicy inside.  This is definitely going to be my go-to recipe for breaded chicken.

I have used this recipe many times.  I added crushed red pepper to the oil also.  After the oil cools i place chicken into oil and let sit for 1/2 hour or so.  I use panko crubs in with my parm bread crumbs.  I also season the breast meat with salt and pepper first.  And i always use more garlic than called for.  I like to use this recipe for chicken sandwiches.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe that I have been making for years with just a few changes - try it, you'll love it!!  Instead of the oil use one cube butter or margarine, soften the garlic in the butter to infuse the flavor, remove the crushed garlic clove.  Then combine 5 tsp dijon mustard with the butter, coat the chicken, roll in breadcrumb/parmesan mixture and continue as directed!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/906991.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make a similar dish. For those who had trouble with the cheese adhering, try using panko and fresh grated parmesan, from a chunk of aged parmesan. The pre shredded cheese does not have the correct texture. Forget the green can stuff. That is not even cheese!
You can also dip the chicken in beaten egg before breading instead of coating it with oil. The egg helps the crumbs stick. Then drizzle the oil/garlic mixture over it before baking. Panko makes a very light crispy crust that is delightful when combined with parmesan cheese. It is my go to breading choice, no matter what I am cooking.

None
text:
I wanted a simple, no-frills recipe with loads of taste - and this was just right! I used five cloves of garlic, and added in some garlic powder, onion salt, and pepper into the bread crumb mixture because it's extremely easy to customize this one. I recommend sprinkling on some extra parmesan cheese about five minutes before you remove it from the oven for some extra flavor and crunch. It leaves all sorts of wonderful crunchy bits on the bottom of the pan that you'll want to scrape and pile onto the chicken. The chicken stayed very moist and flavorful, and I imagine it would serve very well for leftovers. If you want a basic garlic chicken recipe, this one is excellent!

This was delicious!  My whole family gobbled it up and wanted more.  The directions weren't clear on making the garlic infused oil so I looked somewhere else and found a recipe to bring the oil to medium heat and add garlic for 3 - 5 minutes.  Take the oil off the heat and let it sit until cool. Then cover for an hour to infuse before using. WE will make this recipe over and over again.

J

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent! Husband loved it; made it twice in a week and a half!   Second time was better than the first. 1) instead of warm the oil/garlic in the pan, I put the oil, minced garlic, and a tiny bit of garlic powder in a ziplock bag and let it sit for about 10 minutes with the chicken breasts in it. ("massage" around to make sure its evenly spread)  2) Used the directed amount of (italian) bread crumbs and parmesan cheese (fresh grated 1/4 cup from a large block)...but in addition added some more garlic powder (eye balled) to the mix. Put in large baggie and shook well.  3) Placed the chicken breasts into the dry mix bag, shake and rub to make sure all is covered. Place in pan, pour rest of mix evenly on top of chicken  Came out FANTASTIC! The extra garlic powder and fresh parmesan REALLY brought out the flavor! I'll definitely keep this recipe around and make it again soon.

This was delicious and looked great, too! The only change I made was adding some Cheddar cheese on top of the chicken for the last 10 minutes of baking. TO THE PERSON WHO DIDN'T WARM THE OIL AND GARLIC TOGETHER...YES, OF COURSE IT MADE A DIFFERENCE IN THE FLAVOR! You MUST warm the garlic in the oil, that's how the garlic infuses its flavor into the oil.

text:
4 stars as is 5 with modifications.  I followed this recipe to a tee the first time and thought the results were pretty good, but not exceptional.  My hubby and I like our food with more complex flavors so I added the following to the breadcrumbs: (approx) 1/2 C honey crunch wheat germ, 1 tsp oregano, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1/4 tsp fresh ground pepper, 1/2 tsp paprika).  Wheat germ adds folic acid, vitamin E, and fiber without affecting the taste.  After dipping the chicken in the garlic oil, I coated it with the crumbs, dipped in egg, and coated it with some more crumbs.  Before putting it in the oven, I drizzed virgin coconut oil on top (butter or olive oil would work too). The hubby liked this dish before I made these changes, but after the changes, he was very enthusiastic about dinner and leftovers and declared that this needed to go in the regular rotation.

I almost forgot to say that I oooked this for the first time for some dinner guests and we all loved it!! Delicious and moist. Linda

text:
I let the chicken marinate in the olive oil and garlic a couple of hours before coating and cooking it. I used minced garlic because I did not have any other. I used some garlic salt on the breasts before coating them.
I also added some seasoned salt to the coating mixture just to spice it up a little. My husband said "this is one of the better ones. It really appealed to my taste." I think I will try Italian bread crumbs next time. The chicken was very moist and tender enough to cut with a fork. I turned the oven to broil for the last 5 minutes just to make them crispier. I will definitely make this again and again.

text:
You wouldnt believe how one little accident can change how you cook . Company was on thier way. dinner was almost ready. getting ready to bread the chicken. when I dropped a whole can of bread crumbs on the floor. Not having any bread in the house(only the rolls for dinner) I popped three or four English muffine in the blender and then mixed it with the cheese,and proceeded to bread the chicken as called for in the recipe.
 What a wonderful discovery. I will never go back to regular dry bread crumbs again.

text:
This is my first review ever but this is the first time I was compelled to leave my thoughts. This recipe was easy and just fantastic with flavor! I am not a big fan of garlic but the flavor with the crispy coating was fantastic! The recipe calls for 2 tsp of garlic, I used 1 tbsp as my family LOVES garlic. Go by tsp not cloves. I used Italian bread crumbs and grated parmesan not shredded parmesan. The chicken was moist and flavorful. Someone recommended after heating oil and garlic to put in plastic bag and add chicken. TERRIFIC IDEA, much less mess. I let the chicken sit for about 30 min in oil/garlic mixture. Then coated and cooked as recipe states. YUMMMMM! I had no left overs. Thank you for a great recipe! Definitely passing on to all my friends!

userID:
3990040
Display Name:
TTV78

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/528453.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious flavor, moist & tender chicken, crispy golden breading crust!  All of these things together in one simple & quick recipe.  The Hubster loves breaded chicken but it usually is egg & flour dipped, so this is such a wonderful alternative.  I usually don't care for baked boneless skinless chicken breasts, but this was out of this world!  For 2 chicken breasts, I used 1/8 cup of oil but left everything else the same, and it was the perfect amount.  I minced the garlic and warmed the oil in a medium skillet.  Just warm!  Don't sizzle your garlic!  When I dipped the chicken in the garlic oil, I pressed a little to make sure that a lot of garlic pieces stuck to it on both sides before dipping in bread crumb mixture.  It was not very difficult at all!  You don't have to use the Parmesan in the green can:  I used fresh but used a zester to finely grate it & it mixed into the bread crumbs just fine.  I used a little over 1/4 cup.  I always prefer fresh Parmesan to the other stuff, & it's well worth it.  We love this dish.  Will definitely be making it again.  Thank you so much for this recipe!

Ohh this was tasty.  My son prefers bone in chix, so I used legs for him (which I put in the oven 25 minutes before) and tenders (20 min) for the spawn and myself.  I cheated and used jarred minced garlic which I mixed in with the bread crumb/parm cheese mixture and added salt, pepper, paprika & onion powder to it as well.  The chicken was soooooo tender and juicy.  Thanks for the easy & tasty recipe Carol!

None
text:
This was quite good!  I made it with butter instead of oil, and I used Italian breadcrumbs.  For recipes like this I always just coat one side of the chicken and bake crumb side up.  That way there's no chance of soggy breadcrumbs on the bottom.  I baked mine at 400 degrees for about 20-22 minutes.  Then I popped them under the broiler just long enough to give them a little more color.  Next time I think Iâd like to try panko instead of the breadcrumbs.  This would also be good with the addition of provolone or mozzarella cheese and spaghetti sauce for chicken parmesan.  UPDATE 4/25/16:  I made this again using panko instead of regular breadcrumbs, and I used oil as directed, instead of the butter I used last time.  Perhaps because I dipped both sides of the chicken in the oil, but only coated one side with the crumbs, the oil splattered in the oven.  Next time I'll use the butter again on one side only, to hopefully prevent the splattering I got this time.

text:
Ok, money is tight because payday is Friday and the holidays are fast approaching.  I needed a recipe that used what I had on hand and came across this one.  After a VERY LONG DAY, arrived home and the beau & I got to work.

YUMMY!  Our fresh garlic went bad so we sauted with a dry garlic - the house SMELLED wonderful!  Can't wait to try this with the good stuff!  We baked it out in a toaster oven (cut one large breast into 4 pieces).  The top started to burn a little so we flipped it halfway.  

It looked as good as it smelled.  We paired it with steamed broccoli and garlic bread.  I'm SO EXCITED I have leftovers for tonight!  Will try it with fresh garlic next time, but I wouldn't change a thing. So flavorful.

text:
Great recipe! I had large thick chicken breasts so I needed more bread crumbs and Parmesan cheese then the recipe called for. Next time I'll either filet the breast or get some that are not quite as thick so you can taste the breading from each side per bite. Because of their size it took approx 40 minutes in the oven. Also, next time I will use a rack as the chicken got a bit soggy at the bottom. I paired this with the recipe for oven roasted asparagus (which also calls for Parmesan cheese) from this website and it was a big hit for my family! Will cook again and again. Easy and delicious!

text:
This is a long review - brace yourself! I give the original recipe 5 stars. I give MY version of this recipe 7 stars! 1) I used more garlic and let it simmer with the olive oil for about 10 minutes. 2) I added a teaspoon of basil, oregano, and half a teaspoon of parsley to the bread crumb mixture. 3) I topped the chicken in the pan with tomato sauce, more basil, sea salt, and pepper. 4) I topped the whole thing with more cheese and croutons. (Yes, croutons. That's a trick I learned from watching Chef John. It makes a nice golden looking topping and is just an amazing crunchiness to contrast with the soft chicken.) There are lots of recipes just like this recipe for Garlic Chicken, but my version is more like Chicken Parmesan. So it just depends on what you like. This is one of those recipes that just gets better the more you modify it. :)

userID:
2129429
Display Name:
*Sherri*
isPro:

followersCount:
746

739
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2306154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a five star recipe just for the simplicity, but for taste it deserves more than five stars. I had two large boneless breast and instead of olive oil I marinated them in a zip-lock most the day in Italian dressing and the garlic. I used Italian bread crumbs and fresh finely grated Parmesan cheese for the coating, I did also put a bit of pepper and fresh oregano for added flavor. A 1/4 cup of each the bread crumbs and cheese coated my two breast perfectly with none leftover. I baked the breast on my stoneware baking sheet coated in olive oil. They baked 40 minutes to a beautiful golden brown crust, and perfectly tender and juicy on the inside. My husband said we never need to fry chicken again.  This paired perfectly with the Sesame Parmesan Zucchini on Allrecipes. I just placed the zucchini slices on the stoneware along with the chicken half way through the bake cycle. I was surprised at how well the coating stayed on my chicken, unlike many egg or milk coated meats I've made where the coating falls off. I'll certainly make this chicken again and again.

text:
425 is a bit high for baking chicken. i've always baked it at 350 to 375. even at 425 it was still somewhat moist just not mouthwatering moist. the bottom breadcrumbs kind of washed away and the ones that were left kind of burned. i followed the recipe pretty close except used butter instead of olive oil and added a bit extra garlic and also used parmesan seasoned bread crumbs (it's all i had). the breadcrumbs overtook the flavor of the garlic so you couldnt really taste the garlic as you would expect to. not too fond of the texture of bread crumbs anyhow. i would have to say this is a great recipe for someone who doesnt know how to cook worth a . just not for me. needs some serious tweaking.

country:
None
text:
The recipe as written was not exceptional, but I had to give credit to Carol for the idea itself.  With a little tweaking, I came up with a new family favorite.  I increased the olive oil to about 3/4 c. and the garlic to about 6-8 cloves minced and added a shake or two of hot pepper flakes to the mixture/marinade before heating it.  I also pounded the chicken a bit and allowed it to marinate in the olive oil mixture for about 2 hours before breading it.  I then used 2 cups FRESH bread crumbs (which my husband thinks makes all the difference in the world) and a little black pepper with the freshly grated Parmesan cheese and presto!  A hit for adults and kids alike!  Works very nicely with tenderloins too.

Display Name:
viridis

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy and so delicious!  This recipe has been a staple in our kitchen for the past year.  We found that using Italian breadcrumbs work best and adds the most flavor.  That being said, the flavor then depends on the quality of breadcrumbs and we've occasionally had to add oregano and salt.  Also, I put the olive oil and garlic in the baking dish first, the put all the chicken in that dish, flip them to make sure they're covered in the oil, then dip in breadcrumbs/parmesan, then back in the dish.  Saves a step, and you waste none of the olive oil.  Any remaining breadcrumbs/parmesan gets sprinkled atop the chicken before it goes into the oven.  Baking time is usually around 20 minutes, or until the crust is browned.  The best recipe for no-fail moist, delicious chicken!

This recipe was very good and so easy to make!!  I did make some changes though and will continue to tweak the recipe a bit.  I added italian seasoning, crushed red pepper, seasoned salt and crushed black pepper to the bread crumb mixture. I served this with my spicy broccoli/cheese/onion casserole and roasted onion potatos.  It was excellent!!

Delightful.. I used Japanese Panko and the chicken came out looking golden and crispy. As suggested by the other reviewers, I used 7 cloves of garlic, minced, and heated them with the butter in a microwave for 30 seconds. Then I marinaded the chicken ( lightly pounded ) a few hours before baking. I used powdered parmesan with the panko, but I added grated fresh parmesan cheese to the chicken during the last 5 minutes of baking. Wonderful recipe.

text:
This chicken has excellent flavor!  I minced fresh garlic and added it to the oil.  I than microwaved the mixture for 40 seconds.  I than dipped in oil than in bread crumb mixture. I added 1/2 TBSP Italian seasoning to the bread crumb mix.  I took someone elses advice and covered the chicken for the first 40 minutes and than uncovered the last 10.  There were pros and cons to that...PRO: My husband said it was the best chicken I ever made!  CON: It didn't get that crispy crust I wanted.  The breading was mushy.  Like I said excellent flavor next time I will bake uncovered.  Hopefully my husband will still think it is the best!:)

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this without any modifications the first time and it was really good.  The next time I made it, I used 4 cloves of garlic, and added about two tablespoons of chopped fresh basil to the olive oil and let it sit as I prepared my side dishes.  This is a good recipe for a quick meal during the week.  For a change of pace, I used Panko (Japanese bread crumbs) instead of regular bread crumbs and sauteed the chicken in a nonstick skillet with a little olive to brown them and then finished them in the oven.  The Panko gives the chicken a nice crunchy crust.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/18618.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Over the last three years I have made this recipe at least two dozen times.  It's easy, smells incredible while its cooking, and looks gourmet when it is done.  First of all, I LUB garlic.  I use at least 5-10 cloves for this recipe. I always double or triple the amount of bread crumb mixture as it goes fast with oil soaked chicken, but it is so simple that you can easily make some on the fly if you run out.  I use chicken breasts from the butcher which include the tender, so my cooking time is about 40 min. at 400. Having the tender attached allows you to stuff some garlic between the tender and the main breast. One more personal recommendation.  I like dipping sauces in general, my wife not so much.  She finds the breasts excellent the way I make them, without some sort of sauce.  I prefer a little sauce because butcher store breasts can be so huge.  The best compliment is Mississippi brand honey-mustard mayonnaise.  Usually found in the deli section at the grocery store.  It's made from egg yolks, and doesn't even have the nutritional information on the jar, so you know it's bad for you.  If you're going to be sinful that's my suggestion.  My mouth is already watering.

text:
I took other reviewers advice and made this recipe and I'm so glad I did. It was easy and delicious. I made a couple of little changes. First off, I used butter instead of the olive oil (naughty me). Also, I used Italian bread crumbs instead of plain. I was disappointed that there wasn't more garlic flavor since I used 5 cloves. Next time I'll use garlic powder, it will make the recipe even easier and will probably stick to the chicken better. This was very good, the crust was crunchy and the meat stayed so moist. This one becomes a permanent part of my recipe file.

text:
I really like this recipe, I just thought I would throw out there that the chicken will turn out even and crispy all around if you elevate it with a cookie cooling rack. Take a cookie sheet, line it with foil set the cooling rack on top and turn the edges of the foil up. The chicken will turn out awesome and the clean up is super easy.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
In this ongoing financial depression we eat A LOT of chicken at our house.  Thanks, Carol, for a really flavorful, easy recipe for the ubiquitous chicken breast!  We are thankful, indeed!  Made the recipe as written and added a little dried basil to the bread crumbs/cheese.  I sliced two plump breasts into four pieces about 3/8ths thick and gave them a light pounding (so they would cook faster).  Doing this also creates more chicken surface for the yummy crumb coating.  At 425 it takes 20 mins for done yet moist chicken and a nicely-browned, just crisp enough coating.  I also made a quick white sauce, adding 1/2 chicken bullion cube and shredded parma.  Could easily dress this up with fancy sides for guests.

I didn't make this exactly, but used it as a guide.  I had chicken thighs and Romano instead of parm, and I didn't want to use that much oil or mince up some fresh garlic, so I sprayed each thigh on all sides with cooking spray, and dredged in a mixture of Romano, bread crumbs, and garlic powder. city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe did make very moist, flavorful chicken!
I read a lot of the reviews and combined them to make these changes...
I used 6 chicken breasts, a whole head of garlic, doubled the bread crumbs and "green canister" Parmesan cheese, and a dash of fresh black pepper. I put the oil/garlic mixture that had cooled off into a resealable bag, added the chicken breasts and squished the oil and garlic around each piece to coat (worked great!). Dipped each piece in the crumb mixture than cooked for 30 minutes at 425 degrees. Added fresh grated Parmesan on each piece of chicken at the table. Served with fresh bread and broccoli.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe and if doubled can serve as the lead in for an evening of leftovers made into chicken parmesan!! Because the chicken stays juicy and tender, I keep marinara on hand...I reheated the leftovers in a small skillet with about a 1/2-3/4 c of water, cover-for about 15min), crack the lid to vent for another 10 min until water evaporates. Heat marinara, pour over top and top with parmesan...This was my favorite chicken parmesan of ALL TIME! Not to mention they were FABULOUS the first night done exactly as written by this talented cook!;))

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
AMAZING! It turned out so moist and delicate! I recommend using good quality bread crumbs (I get mine at a bakery) I didn't measure any of the ingredients, I just eye balled it because this recipe is so simple. I used more garlic because I love garlic, and I added thyme, salt and pepper to the olive oil. I also added some salt and pepper to the bread crumbs. I served it with this salad, which everyone should learn to make because it so simple and fresh: spinach or chopped lettuce, a little bit of finely minced garlic, a splash of rice vinegar, a splash of olive oil (1:1 ratio olive oil and vinegar), some salt and pepper to taste and a squeeze of lime or lemon (if you have it around). The salt is important, its something i'd never think of putting in salad but so good. Happy cooking!

I altered a few things on the recipe, just because I know how we like things, and it came out awesome. I doubled the sauce and the breading, because I used thin-sliced chicken breast. Also, I used half butter and half oil, and about 6 cloves of garlic, and I used plain Panko. I added salt and pepper to the panko. Then I baked them at 425 for 15 minutes and 450 for 3 minutes to brown them up. They were SO delicious! Thank you for this great idea! :)  6/30 - I made them again for my mom and stepfather's welcome home party and everyone lost their minds. We had some leftovers and they weren't as good the next day, so don't hesitate to eat it all that night!

text:
I have made this several times and found the perfect combinatio,  though as written it's ok.  
I marinate breasts in either italian or ranch dressing overnight or for at least 30 minutes, then pound them flat.  The breading I use is 1/2 parm and 1/2 garlic croutons pulsed in a food processor until fine crumbs.  To this I add a little pepper and garlic salt...  Turns out perfect every time and the croutons make it extra crispy.  My kids love it!

userID:
2319178
Display Name:
krisssy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
4
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this a few times, and I finally got it perfect.  I took a little from different raters on this site to match our tastes.  To 1/4 cup olive oil, I added 2 tsp. fresh garlic, fresh rosemary, 1/4 tsp. sea salt (My husband doesn't like too much salt.), and a sprinkle of pepper.  I warmed on low.  The bread crumb mixture was 1/2 cup parmesan cheese, 1/2 whole wheat bread crumbs, and Italian seasoning.  I also rubbed 1 tsp of fresh basil and 1 tsp. of fresh oregano on the chicken breasts before coating with bread crumbs and oil. I baked at 400 degress for 25 minutes.  They were thin chicken breasts.  It came out so amazing.  My husband LOVED it.  Be sure that you don't overcook it.

YUM! This is perfect for an easy weeknight meal, but could easily be dressed up a bit and served to company. The chicken stayed juicy and was very flavorful. I don't usually buy packaged  dried bread crumbs, so  I made fresh bread crumbs by putting a couple slices of whole wheat bread into the food processor, chopping them into crumbs, and then toasting them in the toaster oven at 200Â° until they were dry. The texture was perfect!

This chicken is just amazing! It is moist and tender on the inside, crisp and flavorful on the outside, and somewhere in between the garlic is there. The garlic taste isn't too extremely overpowering which is nice. I use crushed up Ritz crackers for the coating, leaving some big chunks for a crunchier texture. The crackers also brought a nice buttery kind of flavor to the blend. My family now constantly asks for this chicken dinner almost every week they loved it so much. It is just a very very good recipe. (tastes good as a meal with seasoned wild rice cooked in chicken broth and some green beens or blend of vegetables.)

I've made this several times and waited to review it because I had a lot of problems with the recipe.  NOTE: use the canned parmesan cheese, I was using fresh and it burned every time.  This is a good chicken meal, especially when you're in a rush.  I still use fresh parmesan, but I just sprinkle it on during the last five minutes.  Also, I follow another reviewers advice and marinade the chicken in olive oil and garlic for about 12 hours as well.

We just had this for dinner tonight. Very good dish and easy, too! I doubled the plain bread crumbs and cheese and added the following to the mixture (approximates as I don't measure): 1 1/2 TBS oregano; 2tsp basil; 2 tsp red pepper; 2 tsp onion powder and 2 tps garlic powder. A little salt and pepper. I also increased the amount of garlic with the olive oil. Crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. The family loved it. This is a keeper!

city:

region:

country:

text:
This is a wonderful recipe for a pleasant dinner.  It's not difficult to prepare, so it's perfect for the end to a long day at work.  Baked dishes are always something to keep close - a fresh alternative to unhealthy fried concoctions.  If you're a fan of garlic, this is a great recipe. I prepared this for my family tonight and was pleased with the results.  I used organic garlic, so the flavor seemed just perfect for me.  Also, I tweaked the recipe by adding pepper, a little salt, and onion powder to the dry mixture, and simply drudged the meat through the nice mix. It helped balace out the strong smell, and in the end, I think it aided the overall flavor.The sides we had were mashed potatoes from our garden, and green beans stirred with pepper and bacon for flavor.  Warm apples topped with cinnamon finished off the dessert portion of the meal.  But the chicken was a great staple.  Don't expect a gourmet type of delicacy, as far as the chicken goes.  Be ready for a simple and easy (flavorful) serving of chicken.  Oh, and if you use a convection setting for the bake, make sure to watch the chicken closely, as the cook time will be shorter.

text:
Made this tonight using center cut pork chops and the recipe was delicious w/the pork. I used about 6 cloves of garlic pressed into about 1/2 cup olive oil & gently cooked (don't let the garlic brown) for a few minutes, then dipped the 8 big chops in the garlicky oil,then in the bread crumb mixture. Very easy! Wasn't sure of the time, so went about 55 minutes -- a bit too long, but the crunchy bits on the chops were delicious! Next time will cook for only 45-50 mins for moister chops, but had a great flavor, and went well w/warmed cinnamon applesauce. Tip: line your pan w/non-stick Reynolds foil, and clean-up is a breeze.

text:
It was really moist and garlicky...Yum!  However, I added a lot more garlic...about 9 cloves or so and crushed them myself for added flavor.  Otherwise, it might be bland.  It wasn't overpowering at all.  One thing I would do next time is to add more bread crumb mix.  I used the Garlic & Herb bread crumb mix and added more garlic salt to the mix.  I salt & peppered my chicken individually before mixing, and let it sit in the marinade overnight in the fridge.  I'm already craving this garlic chicken!  Oh, I used boneless, skinless thighs and were perfect...cheaper too! (frozen)

text:
This chicken was unbelievably delicious -- the flavour was wonderful! I followed some of the advice of others: I used six cloves of garlic, minced and lightly warmed with the olive oil. I also mixed in some garlic seasoning with the bread crumbs and parmesan. I added melted margerine (instead of butter) to the bottom of the baking pan as suggested by some people, however I would recommend keeping an eye on the chicken if you do so as it burned, and burned the bottom of some of the smaller pieces of chicken. (I think I'll use cooking spray next time.) A wonderful recipe that was fairly simple. I will definitely make this again!

text:
I always come back to this recipe. Easy, delicious and adaptable. Works with fillets, pieces or smaller chunks (like nuggets of real chicken)
Just as delicious cold the next day. Great for picnics.
Update 2016: still a favourite. I like to add something green to the crumbs (dried Italian herb mix or parsley, chopped fresh chives) Makes it look pretty (can't buy seasoned breadcrumbs here)
I also try to heat the olive oil and garlic in advance if I can. Letting it infuse for an hour or two enhances the flavour even more. 2018 - have now been making this recipe for  twelve years. Itâs great. Itâs reliable. Itâs always impressive. Try it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't really follow recipes, I just kind of modify them. I heated the olive oil and 1 tablespoon of garlic salt on the stovetop. I boiled the chicken part way so the outside was cooked and the inside was still uncooked. I then put the chicken and olive oil mixture into a large Tupperware container and shook it. I let that sit for about 5 minutes and then drain the oil. Instead of regular bread crumbs and parmesan cheese, I used Italian bread crumbs and mozzarella cheese and put it in the Tupperware and shook it as well. Made sure the cheese and bread was covered on the chicken and baked covered on 400 for 40 minutes

text:
I LOVE this chicken, and everything about it! I prefer to use panko instead of traditional bread crumbs though. I advise you cut slits in the chicken so it cooks on the inside faster. And go ahead and try popping 4 or 5 cloves of garlic instead of 2. Creates a more intense garlicky flavour. I also like adding some salt, black pepper, and paprika to the breadcrumb mixture. Try it, and you'll for it too!

text:
Very simple, quick, and tasty.  My husband and teenage stepson ate every last bite (which gave me no leftovers for lunch - bummer!).  I did use more garlic than called for (3-4 tsp) because we love garlic.  I also added about a tsp of Sriracha to the oil/garlic mix, because we love spicy, too - next time (and there WILL be one) I will use even more.  The "shake-and-bake" method did work the best for coating the chicken.  I had shredded parm, so it didn't really stick to the chicken, but I sprinkled it on top and it made a delicious crust.  I used Italian bread crumbs and added paprika.  Baked at 400 for 20-25 minutes and it was crispy outside and tender inside.  I paired this with fresh roasted green beans sprinked with lemon juice and sea salt, and whole wheat pasta dressed with a little butter and sun-dried tomato pesto.  YUM!  Thanks for sharing a delicious, easy main dish!

userID:
8581195
Display Name:
angelinamarie3
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5239802.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really wanted to give this more than 3 stars... but it REALLY LACKS IN FLAVOR! (And the bake temp is TOO HIGH!!) As is, it is pretty dry & bland.
I even took the advice of another review & coated the chicken in Italian dressing instead of olive oil. The dressing idea worked well- I'm sure it turned out better than what it would have been using the oil. But I REALLY wish I would have added some additional seasonings to this dish. More garlic (in powder form), some onion powder, SALT, pepper, etc... is IDEAL to mix in w/ the bread crumbs to coat the chicken. 
I also liked the suggestion of other reviews to use the very finely grated, nearly powder parmesan (like the Kraft green bottle). I left the fresh grated to sprinkle on top just before baking. I also mixed half regular bread crumbs & half panko... the coating result w/ those adjustments was AMAZING! (If only the dish had more flavor & less of a bake temp...) 
So when it comes to baking temp- 425 is TOO HIGH! Yes, the dish may cook a bit faster, but it was EXTREMELY dry. Not moist & tender. Next time will try 350-375. Dryness + lack of flavor left us resorting to ranch & honey mustard for a dipping sauce. 
Will make again, but w/ some major adjustments & less of a bake temp. Definitely read some of the more critical reviews & follow advice if making this! A good base- but needs a LOT more flavor & a few adjustments.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy! I honestly did not expect much of this even though the reviews seem to rave about it. I was proven absolutely wrong! The flavors meld together really well. Made this with strips of boneless chicken thigh and had it with a salad. I liked it so much I made it again the next day, this time increasing the garlic and reducing the olive oil. Prefer it with more garlic and less oil. I heated the minced the garlic and olive oil in the micro on low for two minutes, stirring every thirty seconds. Also added some chili flakes because I like the heat. Added the chicken to the garlic/oil mixture and mixed to coat, and then added the parm/bread crumbs to the same bowl. Less clean up! Gave the parm/bread crumbs mixture a few whirs in the blender so that the chicken would look just like fried chicken, and not have the little parm flakes sticking out after baking. I definitely see myself making this over and over again. So easy, and tastes amazing.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was sooooo easy AND delicious! Had it with sauteed broccoli and spinach salad with an olive oil/basalmic dressing. AWESOME! AWESOME! AWESOME! This one is going into the regular rotation!!!   I used an infused olive oil and not plain olive oil and we used 3 cloves of garlic.  Our chicken breasts were large so we needed triple the parmesan and breadcrumbs.  I think some of the negative reviews are because of a few possibilities:

People didn't dry their chicken before dredging in the oil.
They skipped the step of warming the oil with the garlic or needed more garlic.
They used an unflavored olive oil that wasn't "pure" olive oil; hence- no flavor. (The bottle will only list "olive oil" in the ingredients if it is pure.)
They used butter instead of olive oil and butter WILL burn faster than olive oil and make it soggy.
Using low-fat Italian dressing? No comparison to the pure olive oil & its health benefits!

For a TV/Football snack or appetizer, I used this same recepe for years, but for snacks, I use drumsticks and wings.  Just adjust the cooking time (less), and cook under the broiler for a couple minutes at the end to get the crust a little more cruchy.  Manga!  Don't go too heavy on the breadcrumbs, but add more garlic!  Olive oil is a must and regular is better than EVOH, less smoking.

text:
This is simply delicious!!!  Made it today and used 5 cloves of garlic for more flavor.  I also used Panko bread crumbs w/ my grated Parmesan cheese (in the can) mixture.  I used a little more olive oil than required which left me w/ a nice garlicky sauce that I couldn't waste.  So, I made some angel hair pasta.  I took 1/2 cup of my salted pasta water and threw it in w/ my garilc/oil sauce and then added 1/2 cup diced red bell peppers.  I brought this sauce to a simmer and poured it over my hot pasta .  I mixed in a little seasoning salt and I ended up w/ a perfect garlic pasta dish to go w/ my garlic chicken.  Chicken was moist and delicious but the garlic pasta? Out of this world!!!

I'll probably try garlic salt in place of the crushed garlic next time, but only because the crushed garlic was tough to evenly distribute throughout each piece.  I adore the simplicity of this recipe, though.  Definitely saved to the recipe box.

SO GOOD!  I added more garlic (because I'm obsessed with it), minced it with a grater into the EVOO so that the garlic would coat the chicken, which it did perfectly.  Sprayed a very light layer of olive oil onto the baking dish because I didn't want the crumbs to stick to it, then lined a light layer of bread crumbs over that.  Baked for a total of 35 minutes @ 375.  It turned out crunchy and moist.  So easy to prepare!

text:
I was so excited about the reviews this recipe got, that I didn't really look further than the first 10 reviews.  The only changes I made were to double the amount of garlic (we love it) and added additional bread crumbs and cheese because 1/4 cup just wasn't enough to coat 4 breasts.  Two problems came up: 1) 425 is way too high to cook this chicken; mine began burning about 15 minutes in so I decreased to 375. 2) it was bland, bland bland.  I thought the garlic would give it a garlicky taste  - we couldn't taste anything.  It was like I breaded some chicken in plain bread crumbs and baked.  I would have been better off using Shake N' Bake.  I can't understand the almost 5 star review unless people are just changing the recipe or haven't had flavorful chicken.  I like the idea of the olive oil so that is why I gave it a 2 star rating.

I usually don't review if I've made changes, but this chicken was so good, and the changes were small.  Per another review I used butter instead of olive oil; I used 4 cheese Italian, (provolone, asiago, parm & romano) because that's what I had on hand, and used panko bread crumbs.  I baked it on a rack placed on a cookie sheet so it got crispy on the bottom also.  This chicken was so moist and tender, no knife was needed.  Will definitely keep this as a go to chicken recipe. text:
I used some thinly sliced boneless/skinless breasts and I only needed to bake them about 10 minutes.  I used panko crumbs.  I also increased the olive oil mixture and added some crushed red pepper.  After I had dipped and breaded the chicken, I put the oil back on the stove to simmer.  

I boiled some whole wheat pasta and tossed that with the oil mixture.  

When the breasts were done I put them under the broiler for a couple of minutes to get them a little more brown and crisp.  Very nice dish.

text:
The chicken breast I get are big and thick. I slice then through the middle to make them smaller. I add salt pepper and mrs. dash. I don't like parmesaen so I used italian-style panko bread crumbs. The smaller thinner pieces make to have more flavor and the panko breading is perfect. use less heat, try 400 degrees for thinner pieces instead. Thick cuts of meat to season properly needs to be seasoned and set overnight in a container to get in the flvor and get juicy.

text:
I  have made this twice now. The first time I did it I followed the recipe exactly. It gets 4 stars for these reasons...1. You need to double the breading in my opinion and 2. I think it could use a little bit more flavor. Therefore the second time I made it I doubled the breading mixture and skipped the oil and garlic mixture all together... instead I marinated my chicken in italian dressing then coated it in the mixture. Turn out AMAZING! The original recipe is good but just too average.

text:
This dish was amazing. I am not an experienced cook at all and it was easy enough for me to do, make it taste good, and use ingredients that I had at home. I used chicken tenderloins instead of the breasts, which also reduced my cooking time to about 20 mins or so. I also used the grated parmesan in a bag instead of the 'green can' and used a lot more fresh garlic than suggested. The chicken came out crispy, crunchy, and so delicious! Don't make too much if you're on a diet because you will eat it all!

text:
This is the easiest chicken I've ever made, and it turned out fantastic.  I used 5 large cloves of fresh garlic, smashed them with the flat side of a knife, and simmered them in the olive oil for about 5 minutes.  When I read the recipe, it was unclear whether or not to strain out the garlic before dipping the chicken into it.  I ended up leaving the smashed garlic cloves in the oil, and some of the smashed garlic stuck to the chicken.  This was a good thing, and the flavor was absolutely fantastic.  Enjoy!

text:
This was really good, but I was short on time so I streamlined it a bit.  After I warmed the oil and garlic, (I made extra so I could saute fresh spinach), I poured the whole bit in the bottom of a 9x13 pan.  I rotated the breasts in the oil, and then I sprinkled the breadcrumbs on top of the chicken.  Finally I topped w/ shredded parm. cheese.  I served this w/ angel hair pasta, marinara sauce, and sauteed spinach.  It was really good,and if you ladled a bit of the marinara over the chicken it tasted like chicken parm.  Will make again!

I've really been into using the oven lately because I like to forget about things while they cook.  This was very simple and tasted like it wasn't.  I used Italian breadcrumbs, and romano cheese, and the chicken didn't even need salt.  I warmed up 3 large crushed cloves in oil, and it was plenty.  I used 3 large chicken breasts and halved them.  I added more cheese, but that's my preference.  It came out great.  VERY SIMPLE.  Worth giving a try!  Would be great as chicken parm, or in a sandwich or on a salad.

text:
These turned out extremely moist and flavorful. For some reason I needed twice the breadcrumb & cheese mix, but the breasts were rather large. I added fresh ground pepper to the mix as well as 1 tsp basil and 1 tsp oregano. Five minutes before they were done, I covered with shredded mozzarella cheese and continued to bake until well melted. This was served over a bed of spaghetti and topped with a garlic-marinara sauce. I have found that lightly greasing or using cooking spray on the baking dish ensures that clean up is a snap!

text:
This is one of my very favorite not-a-lot-of time/energy to cook weeknight meals.  I make it even speedier by cutting the chicken breasts into bite sized pieces while I'm nuking the oilive oli/garlic (about 1 min).  I like it in pieces because it's quicker and it gets a little crispier!  I spray the bites w/PAM before I put them in the oven.  I usually spread frozen green beans on a cookie sheet, drizzle w/EVOO, sea salt, bread crumbs, and parm and bake beside the chicken.  Thanks for a great recipe!!!

I just made this tonight and it turned out FABULOUS! I made it as directed but did add a few spices to the crumbs since I prefer using plain crumbs and then seasoning them as I like. Just a few shakes of Italian seasonings, some celery seed and a little salt and pepper. It was moist, flavorful and perfect! This is absolutely a repeater.

text:
Very good! I added some seasonings to the bread crumb mixture to add flavor. I found that using crushed Ritz crackers stick more to the chicken when used. When I use Ritz crackers I like to not crush them completely but leave a little bit of chunks for a crunchy chicken coating. I also added more garlic to the garlic and olive oil mixture because I thought the recipes amount just wasn't enough for a garlic flavor to even come out.

Made this as an alternative to the ham at my Easter Potluck for those who avoid pork. GREAT, moist, tasty, EASY recipe. I used "garlic seasoned breadcrumbs." Instead of infusing the garlic in the oil by heating it, I marinated the meat in a ziplock bag with the olive oil and garlic for  24 hours. Good leftover and added to a salad.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first few times it was OK. . . Then I made them for a crowd and it was the hit of the night.  It was perfect for a party.  I cut and pounded the chicken into smaller sizes.  My family had them as "finger" food, others made small sandwhiches, while others put a little tomato sauce over them.  I made the garlic oil early in the day and let the flavor mix in with the chicken for a couple hours in the refrigerator.  If you can find fresh bread crumbs from a baker, it is even better.  But don't leave out the cheese, it really is what makes it taste great. (also a little hot pepper in the oil also kicks it up just a little)

text:
This is such a quick and easy recipe, and the chicken turns out beautifully every time; tender and moist and with great flavor.  I have been making this recipe for years after discovering it here on Allrecipes.com, and I highly recommend it.  For a slight variation, use Italian seasoned bread crumbs.  Also, I have substituted crushed cracker crumbs when I have been out of bread crumbs.  I also like to pound/flatten the chicken breasts before coating them so that they are thin and bake more quickly.

text:
For such a simple little recipe, this made a very tasty dinner. I used fairly thick chicken breast so I did have to bake a little longer. The thing I noticed most about this chicken recipe was that it turned our very moist. Instead of baking at 425 for 30 minutes, I covered the dish and  baked at 350 degrees for 40 minutes then removed the cover and baked for another 10 minutes. I think this may have been the reason it was so moist.

userID:
1479023
Display Name:
cookiequeen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
90
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
227
favoritesCount:
283
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/72.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
DELICIOUS..I think any chicken needs to sit in marinade for hours before cooking for the ultimate moistness- so I always sit mine in buttermilk(if none on hand mix 1cup milk with 1TBS white vinegar or lemon juice) for a few hours.  Then I heated the olive oil and 6 or 7 cloves of garlic crushed up and cut up and let it simmer in a frying pan for like 20min on low to draw out the great garlic flavor. I transfered that to a bowl and let cool for a minute then patted off the chicken sitting in buttermilk and added to oil/garlic mixture.  I let that sit for a few more hours and then breaded(needed a little more bread crumb mixture then what it called for and salt and pepper) and baked uncovered in 13x9 inch glass pan for 30 minutes.  Probably was ready in 25min.  Very moist and very delicious.  Not an extreme garlic taste either-just right.
If no time for all the marinating I would def recommend  at least letting it sit in oil/garlic mixture for awhile.
Thanks-will make again real soon!

text:
Great recipe! However, I have one suggestion: don't use real parmesan. The 3 times I have made this recipe I have used freshly grated paremsan. When visiting my mother I suggested she make this easy recipe, she did not have real parmesan on hand, so she used the dried parmesan you buy in the green can. I thought it would come out tasting bad, but it actually came out better. This may just be a personal preference, so when you make this the second time (and I know you will) you should switch up the type of parmesan you are using to figure out which you like best.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very good. My family are all garlic-holics, so I used a lot more garlic. I had 9 breasts, and used about 1/4 cup of the store bought pre-chopped garlic from the jar. I added salt and pepper to the oil mixture and let the chicken marinate in the fridge for an hour. I also added garlic powder to the seasoned bread crumb mixture. Several other reviewers said that they had trouble with burning, so I turned the heat to 375. I checked them after 30 minutes and they weren't browning much, so I flipped them and raised the temp to 400. I think they should cook at a higher heat, if you want them brown and crispy. The family all gave a thumbs up, so I will add this to our family's menu. Next time I'll try cooking at the temp it calls for. I'd give this 5 stars for ease of preparation, and a solid 4 for taste. Thanks for a keeper!

text:
I've tried this recipe twice now.  The first time I baked it in the oven and the results were soggy.  This DEFINITELY benefits from being pan-fried rather than baked; although it's a bit more labor-intensive that way, the results are definitely worth the effort.  Kids love it, nice and crispy, and I just sauteed it in the garlic (used extra) and oil that I had marinated it in (which I also recommend, by the way).  Just a few minor revisions made a huge difference!

text:
VERY GOOD! This chicken got compliments all around the table.  Because I have a wheat allergy, I toasted some ENER-G tapioca bread and used that for the dry bread crumbs (my family never knew!). I also followed another reviewers advice and marinated the chicken in the olive oil & garlic for about 30 minutes and then rolled the breasts in the bread crumbs and parmesan. I used 1/4 cup melted butter in the dish and as it cooked, it made wonderful crunchy bits from the overflow breading, which everyone fought over! Just excellent.  Will try with pork chops next time!

text:
Nothing spectacular here.  I actually thought chicken breast with bone in and skin on would've helped.  I followed the recipe to the letter and tried adding more "oomph" with pepper flakes, but it was just average at best.  I seared the chicken with skin on in the garlic oil, then dredged the breading on the chicken (which wouldn't stick, so I drizzled the rest of the oil onto the chicken, that made the breading stay).  Served this with fettucine alfredo (which was excellent).  Nice meal, but this chicken wasn't worth it (and it was easy to say the least).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken went to the top of my list.  Absolutely loved it.  It was flavorful and moist enough to cut with a fork. 
Followed the recipe with these minor modifications suggested by previous reviewers:
- used half olive oil half butter
- seasoned chicken with onion powder and black pepper
Next time for my normal portion of 2 chicken breast halves, I will :
- use 1/3 c each seasoned bread crumbs and parmesan as well as slightly reducing the amounts of olive oil and butter
- reduce baking time to  20 minutes then add the grated parmesan on top and bake another 5 minutes.  
-  increase cloves of garlic to 5  
BTW, I buy shredded parmesan then use a mini processor to grate.  Perfect and much better than the "green can".
Thanks to Carol for this tasty recipe and  to reviewers for their  suggestions.

text:
Great tasting dish and easy to make.  I used the unused garlic oil and parmesan/breading mix to bread and roast some asparagus.  Putting in the roasted vegetables with about 10 minutes left gave them a crusty shell but soft inside.  It only added one additional dish to clean up but no extra time.  I cooked the chicken for 30 minutes and the asparagus for 10.

text:
We love this! Make it all the time. I use both Panko and Italian Breadcrumbs, and it always turns out great. 

I tenderize the breasts, soak in the garlic/olive oil infusion for about 30 mins - an hour, then in a ziploc I shake the chicken up with the breadcrumb/parmesan mixture and bake it. Serve with rice and steamed veggies. AMAZING. Never any leftovers.

userID:
13508679
Display Name:
Susan
isPro:

madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this twice and it was awesome. I put 5 smashed garlic cloves in glass measuring cup with 1/2 cup extra virgin oil and heated it up to hot. Removed it from microwave and let it cool down for a couple hours so the oil would fuse with garlic. Dipped chicken in garlic oil then in equal parts of Italian bread crumbs and Parmesan cheese with about a heaping tablespoon of dried parsley. Lined a 9x13 Pyrex dish with Reynolds non stick foil. Took some of the remaining oil and drizzled a thin stripe down each breast. Put it on the bottom rack in the oven and baked them for 35 min. Fantastic.  The breasts were good sized out of the fresh meat counter at my supermarket. I rinsed them in warm water dried them first. Never use ice cold chicken.

A new family favorite! I made this even easier by changing one small step: put the olive oil and garlic directly into a shallow bowl, and microwave for 30 seconds. This may vary depending upon your microwave, but you can smell the garlic permeating the olive oil & know that it is ready. I followed the rest of the recipe as written. Yum!

text:
I used 4 cloves of garlic in the oil instead of 2 because mine looked smallish.  I made this with Italian seasoned panko bread crumbs and fresh parmesan (not the kraft stuff) and it was great.  I did have to increase the breadcrumbs and parmesan mixture to 1/3 cup each but my chicken breasts were huge.  I had no breading left over.  In the future, I think I'll make this with chicken tenders or thinly sliced chicken breasts.   Super easy dish and it tasted amazing.

13667477
Display Name:
Crybaby

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6485113.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Another way to make this is to slice the whole chicken breasts in half lengthwise so they're thinner. Use half melted butter and half oil and yes, use about 5 crushed garlic cloves. Then cover a baking sheet with foil, put a grate on top of it and then spray the grate with Pam right on top of the foiled sheet. Then double the bread crumbs and the Parmesan (even better with Romano) and add some crushed dried oregano into the breadcrumb mix, along with some red pepper flakes and some freshly ground black pepper.  Preheat the oven to 350 and then cook the chicken for about 20 to 25 minutes, depending on how thin your breasts were.  This will work, too, even if you use the boneless chicken breasts whole -- just use your thermometer to check the temperature prior to removing from oven. I still think keeping the oven at 350 is a better temp than the hotter oven. It keeps the chicken breasts crispier on both sides. I often make a mustard sauce made with heavy cream to put over the chicken if you're looking to jazz up this recipe a bit.  Delicious.

text:
Great easy recipe! Just a few changes that took this recipe from great to extraordinary....
Double garlic, add 1/2 tsp. crushed black pepper,and 1/2 tablespoon oregano. Heat on very low heat for ten minutes, then allow to cool. (If you can, make the infused olive oil in the morning,and let sit all day.) To the breading mixture of Italian bread crumbs and parmesan cheese, add some finely crushed French's fried onions. Outstanding! This recipe/combo also works well to make chicken parmesan, just use thinner cuts of chicken and top with your own sauce and provolone or parmesan cheese after baking chicken, then put on low under broiler for a couple minutes!

text:
I have now made this recipe twice.  The first time, I did it per the directions and it was wonderful.  The only thing I didn't like about the recipe as written is that it didn't have much garlic taste.  I also thought the coating could be a little more crunchy. 

I made it again last night and made a couple of changes.  I used Progresso Panko crumbs (Italian flavored) and instead of crushing the garlic, I pressed it.  The other thing I did, on accident, was to heat the garlic in the oil until the garlic was sizzling.  The garlic flavor was absolutely wonderful and I loved the crunch of the panko crumbs. 

This is definitely a recipe that will go into my recipe rotation.

text:
This was INCREDIBLE!!! I had to use GLUTEN FREE breadcrumbs (homemade... 1/2 cup blended rice chex, 1 tablespoon Italian seasoning, 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder, 1/4 teaspoon salt. keep in sealed container in fridge) I used 1/4 of that, I also used 5 cloves of garlic instead of 2 and I'm glad I did because the garlic wasn't overpowering at all. This tasted Amazing and hubby couldn't stop saying how good this tasted. THANK YOU!!!

text:
I made this following the recipe, but using butter instead of olive oil. 

The positives: it was super easy and quick. The chicken was juicy and tender. My kids loved it.

The negative: it was soggy on the bottom (and not very crispy on the top either!), and a little too bland for the adults. Maybe it just needs a bit more seasoning, but I think the sogginess would still be off-putting for me.

Overall: there are better baked chicken recipes out there!!

text:
So so so delicious! If you prep as instructed-delicious. If you are ok to alter it a bit then use butter instead of Olive oil. Also I added 1/4 butter slices around the chicken before baking and poured the garlic infused butter in the pan as well. I baked at a lower heat for a little bit longer. Then (at the advice of another review) I took all the extra juice (plus parmesan/bread crumbs) and put in a small pan. Added 1 tbls cornstarch, 1/4 water, some half and half (or evaporated milk). Made a nice rich gravy to put on chicken served over a bread of brown rice.

text:
This recipe is fantastic! I have an idea to get rid of that soggy bottom. Try preheating the (greased) chicken dish in the oven, then when it's up to temp, and the chicken is ready to go, place the chicken on the hot baking dish. That'll give it a nice sear. Might even cut back on the cooking time and give you a nice crust.

Good and easy.  I used focaccia bread crumbs with a little dried basil and garlic powder.  I forgot to mix the parmesan with the bread crumbs so I sprinkled some on top before putting it in the oven.  Then I flipped the chicken halfway through the cooking time and sprinkled a little more on the other side.  Mine was cooked through after 25 minutes at 375, but the chicken pieces were exactly 4 oz each.  Will make again.

text:
A little on the bland side.  If you coat both sides of the chicken and put in a baking dish you end up with one side just being a soggy mess.  You need to bake on some sort of wire rack to allow both sides to end up with the nice crispy coating.  Otherwise you might as well only coat one side and save the calories.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this dish last night using two large BSC breasts. Even though I only cooked two breasts, I made the EVOO/garlic mix and the bread crumbs (as someone suggested, I used Italian bread crumbs) and parmesan cheese mix as directed for four chicken breasts. I had a little garlic oil left (btw, I heated the oil and garlic together in a small skillet on low for probably 30-40 min.), but the parmesan bread crumbs worked just right. Since I was only cooking for two, I bought large chicken breasts so that we could split one for last night's dinner and eat the remaining one, probably, tomorrow night. As soon as I cut one in half for my wife and I to share, I was pretty sure we had a winner. I've cut refrigerated stick margarine that was more difficult to cut than these chicken breasts. No, no tenderizer and no pounding, just two fresh BSC breasts. Because of their thickness, I baked them for more like 45 min. and nothing burned or browned excessively. If you haven't tried this recipe already, you owe it to yourself to give it a try.

This recipe is good with variations. First off, I added my own blend of Italian spices to the bread crumbs... don't forget to add the salt and pepper that this recipe forgot should have included. Next time I'll make sure to serve it with some gravy too.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
1
userID:
9651889
Display Name:
Couponmami
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
23
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/865735.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews and adding my own touches to it I ended up with a flavorful juicy new chicken dish being added to my family meals. Recipes tweeked as followed: *Preheat oven to 375 (for easier cleanup I recommend lining pan with foil) *I used chicken tenders instead of whole breast. * I seasoned my meat as if I was going to bake it. *I microwaved a little less than 1/4 cup of olive oil and minced garlic(unmeasured) on high for 1min then put chicken in ziplock bag and poured evoo and garlic mix over the meat and mixed it around and let marinate in the fridge for two hrs. *Whole wheat seasoned bread crumbs 1/4 cup *Kraft grated parmesan/romano mixed cheese (green container) 1/2 cup * mix cheese and bread crumbs together and I added seasoning to the dry mix as well. *coated chicken with dry mix and covered pan with foil and baked for 18 mins. I then removed foil flipped chicken then broiled until desired crispiness aprox. 10 mins I flipped chicken after 5 mins. Tasty, juicy garlic parmesan chicken with garlic red mashed potatoes and mixed veggies and a happy family enjoying a new meal. Sn: base your dry mix off of how much cicken your cooking and how much more of one taste you would like over another. You only need enough evoo to coat your chicken not saturate it.

text:
I used 1/2 butter, 1/2 EVOO & increased the minced garlic quite a bit.  Heat that in the micro to meld develop flavor.  Butterfly chicken and let it marinade for 2-24 hours. Then bread in 1/2 panko, 1/2 Italian bread crumbs with an equal amount of grated Parmesan. Amazing!!!

text:
Great recipe....whole family enjoyed.  To get up to 2 tsp crushed garlic, I had to crush 7 cloves.  Totally worth the effort though. Love the tip of heating up the olive oil/garlic mixture in the microwave!  Did not add extra bread crumbs as other reviewers mentioned....I think it would deter from the nice garlic balance.  Used thawed chicken tenders and reduced bake time down to 18 mins, then broiled on high for 2 mins to crisp them up.  Adding this to our weekly menu....and pinning it!!

This is my go to chicken recipe! I make it with a few changes : I add 2 tablespoons of minced garlic to the oil and heat that on low for 5 to 10 minutes.  I then whisk one egg and dip the chicken before dipping it in the garlic olive oil. I also use Italian bread crumbs ( more flavor)

text:
I made this tonight and bf and I loved it. I had two thick chicken breasts (1.3 lbs total) that I sliced in half for 4 thinner pieces. I kept all the other measurements the same. I only keep plain panko crumbs (nice crunch!) but I seasoned them with Italian seasoning. 
Also I left the garlic in oil +1 tbl butter over low for about 30 mins. 
After baking for the 35 mins, they were cooked but not brown on top. Turned on broiler for 3 mins and it was perfectly golden brown. 
Easy to make and tasty.
Thanks for the recipe :)

text:
A good recipe to have in your arsenal, but be prepared to play around with it a bit. I upped the garlic and parmesan, and also added some herbs to the breadcrumbs based on some reviews here, but it still didn't give it quite the kick I wanted. Next time I think I'll use Italian seasoned bread crumbs and fiddle around with that a bit more. I also think it would really benefit from having some kind of sauce served with it. This would probably be really great with a fettucini alfredo or a chicken parm recipe.

text:
Not a lover of chicken, but decided to try it with some of the suggested modifications from other viewers.  I think I probably should have stuck with the original recipe.  I used panko bread crumbs, and used ziplock bags to coat the chicken with oil and the breadcrumb mixture.  The resulting coating was not that great...it just didn't cover much of the chicken and didn't get very brown and crispy.  It wasn't that flavorful even though I also added pepper and Italian seasoning.  However, my picky husband liked it and had seconds, which is often more telling of how good a recipe is.  So take my review with a grain of salt, I don't really like chicken to begin with and didn't follow the recipe exactly.  I will make it again to see if I like it better with the original recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is fantastic as is or with Italian bread crumbs instead of plain. Since it's just me and my husband, we use the leftovers for a super easy and tasty Chicken Parmesan. Just put a little marinara on the bottom of a baking pan and top with chicken breasts. Then, top those with more marinara and a pile of Italian blend cheese (mozzarella, parmesan, asiago... whatever) and put in the oven at about 350. Once the cheese is melted, crank up the broiler to get tasty brown bubbly bits on top. Serve with spaghetti and enjoy!

dateLastModified:

userID:
2317510
Display Name:
MagnoliaSouth
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
35
favoritesCount:
83
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1182240.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If I could give this 4 1/2 stars, I'd do it for sure. This was very good, but in the future it will need some adjustments. I followed it to the letter (except that I used Italian bread crumbs because that's all I had) and had a few problems. First off, the oil was too much. I'll decrease that by half next time. Also, the garlic doesn't really stick well to the chicken, so next time (even though I much prefer fresh garlic), I'll add garlic powder to the crumb mixture instead OR I'll try it one more time with the decreased oil and see if that works better. Next time I'll stick with the Italian bread crumbs, but instead of 1/4 c. I will combine 1/3 c. of each the Parmesan and the crumbs. I'll put them in a shaker and then sprinkle it evenly over each in the baking dish, then turn them over and sprinkle them again. All in all this was a great fast dish and I'll definitely make it again, it just had too much of one thing and not enough of the other.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-08-19T18:08:20.317
helpfulCount:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out really well! Here's what I did differently: I also used butter with the olive oil & garlic...& since i could not find crushed garlic anywhere (where do you find it??) I used minced garlic instead...mixed those 3 ingredients & microwaved them until the butter was melted & it was warm.  I also did not measure anything--I just went by what looked right. Dipped the chicken in that mixture, then dipped it in a mixture of parmesean cheese, Italian style bread crumbs, & garlic powder.  Baked for almost 30 min...came out great. I'll definitely make this again as long as the man approves. :)

text:
Simple and tasty chicken dish.  I used butter instead of oil, and seasoned panko crumbs (in place of bread crumbs).  Didn't measure out the garlic, but used about 6 small cloves.  Also, I found that I had to double the crumb/cheese mixture to cover all four of the chicken breasts.
Thank you for an easy midweek dinner!

text:
AMAZING!!! EASY, smelled AWESOME cooking!!! The only thing I did different was I maranated the chicken with olive oil/garlic mixture for about an hour!! Make sure you use a meat thermometer to check for doneness. Overcooked=DRY CHICKEN! I had a wireless meat probe and it showed the temprature as it was cooking and beeped at 175 degrees to signal doneness; PERFECT!!!!

text:
Pretty good; maybe my expectations were too high after reading the stellar reviews. It was bland; next time I'll add Italian seasoning. I used real Parmesan (not that grated Kraft junk), and that was good; and I had only 2 breasts, both 8 oz., and the cooking time was spot-on. I used the amount of garlic called for, but it got lost; I'll add more next time. I served it along side steamed broccoli and angel hair pasta with some Kraft garlic cooking sauce I'd gotten for free and had to finish up.

text:
This was simply delicious!  I used Italian bread crumbs.  Only one thing could enhance it - brining the chicken breasts to ensure juiciness, especially if they are thick.  Here's the brining method I used:

Whisk together 6 c. warm water, 1/2 c. salt, 1/4 sugar, then add one lemon quartered and juiced.  Place up to 6 skinless, boneless chicken breast halves in the brine and refrigerate (covered) for one hour.  Rinse and pat dry.

text:
I have tons of chicken recipes and this will be a new one to add on. Very quick and easy. I also salted the chicken, and doubled the breadcrumbs (I used Panko) and parmesan cheese. I also used 2 large garlic cloves and heated it a bit in the oil. No other changes. The bake time was good. Not dry at all. The only problem I had, which wasn't really a problem, was that they didn't brown as much as I would have liked. Perhaps my pyrex wasn't shallow enough. I just quickly turned on the broiler to brown them.  Just to edit. I made this a second time and didn't like it as much. I doubled the bread crumbs and cheese, which was a mistake. I would double the breadcrumbs but not the Parmesan. It tasted too cheesy and was mushy underneath. I also think I went overboard on the garlic.

text:
First off I have made chicken in bread crumbs many times for my family but... This was AMAZING! I Used butter instead of Olive oil. I did split the breasts to make them thinner and this was great to reduce cooking time. I did up a whole family pack of boneless breasts. What I did not need for Dinner I placed on Parchment lined pan and froze them. After they were Frozen I wrapped them tightly in foil an places in a zip top bag. They were almost better 2 weeks later when I took them out for a quick dinner. This will definitely become a stable in my dinner rotation!  THANKS!

this is VERY good!  turns out super juicy and tender, and I like that there are no processed ingredients, and it's ingredients that I have on hand.
