This is a simple and good way to season chicken.  I made it with very thick chicken breasts, so the cooking time was more like 37-40 minutes.  Didn't have grated parm, so I subbed shredded. None
text:
Incredibly simple, and so flavorful!! I used seasoned bread crumbs and added an additional teaspoon of Italian seasoning to the bread crumb mixture. After placing the breasts in the dish, I sprinkled them with garlic powder and baked for about 35 minutes. They are so moist and delicious! That said, I did not taste much of a garlic flavor. I used 5 tablespoons of olive oil and 2 teaspoons of garlic for five breasts, but I will increase the garlic next time. Nevertheless, the flavor was amazing as is. Wonderful paired with brown rice, corn, and a side salad. I'm keeping this one around for company!!

text:
This was a VERY good dinner! I had all the ingredients at home, which was EXACTLY what i was looking for since I dont have much right now...Technically, I didn't have the bread crumbs but I made my own for the first time and succeeded very well. The only changes to the recipe that i made were adding my usual spices (onion adn garlic powder, red pepper flakes, celery salt, italian seasoning, salt, pepper...). I processed it all up and it was delicious. Oh, and i also used fresh parsley. The only problem that I had with the recipe was that the breading started to burn after about 10 minutes, i came back 10 minutes later and it was VERY close to being a lost meal.  had to turn off the oven so that I could still eat. I dont know if this was due to the fact that my breadcrumbs were homemade or may too wet, but still...Otherwise, this was an excellent meal! My dad loved it and rated it as his top 5 all-time meal. and if I do say so myself, thats pretty good!

I pound my chicken breasts so they are the same thickness throughout and will cook at the same rate because I do not like it when the thin ends are dried out.  Therefore, I cooked mine 30 minutes at 375Â°, not 425Â°.  Perfectly juice and soooo tasty.  The family says definitely a keeper.

This was fantastic chicken.  I pounded the chicken thin, used Italian dressing, seasoned the breadcrumbs with granulated garlic and a bit of onion salt.  I baked 25 minutes at 400. I served with Knorr's Creamy Chicken flavored pasta.

None
text:
Absolutely delicious and so easy! I served this for my boyfriend's parents when they came over to visit. I followed a few of the suggestions made and they came out so moist and flavorful. I doubled the recipe, but it only made 6 chicken breasts 1) Baked at 375 for 30 min 2) Pounded chicken breasts  3) Used 1/4 c olive oil & 1/4 c melted butter w/ crushed garlic. 4) Heated the oil, butter,and garlic in the microwave 5) Marinated the chicken in the oil, butter, garlic mixture for an hour 6) Used fresh grated Parmesan cheese and Italian flavored bread crumbs  The dinner received rave reviews! Thank you so much for this recipe!!!

text:
This was pretty good for such a simple recipe.  I followed the recipe very closely, except I used thin-sliced chicken breast filets, which cut cooking time down to about 25 minutes (plus a couple more minutes on broil for a golden-crisp finish).  I also used Progresso Garlic Herb breadcrumbs instead of plain breadcrumbs, which really enhanced the flavor.  I loved how quick and easy this was to make and the cooking aroma was lovely.

text:
New favorite way to make "parmesan chicken".  Have tried many other baked recipes that are not this good. I think the garlic-infused oil is a lot of the key.  Also highly recommend pounding the chicken out.  I also use real parmesan - the kind in the block that has to be grated.  Much much better than the kinds you can buy already shredded in the can.

text:
Excellent.  I chose this recipe when I needed a last-minute dinner idea.  I used chicken strips and baked them for 22 minutes at 400 degrees.  Turned out perfectly.  I dredged the chicken through twice (don't recommend--a bit too oily) and added a bit of seasoned salt to the bread crumb mixture.  It was tasty and juicy.  Next time, I will marinate the chicken in the oil mixture for awhile, and toss in some more seasoning.  This recipe is delicious as-is, and is also ideal for a little personal tinkering.  I give it 4 stars for taste, but add a star because it is so easy and a real crowd pleaser.  With less than an hour from start to table, this recipe will definitely go into rotation.  Thank you!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sooooooo good! Since my husband and I work a lot, I am always looking for quick, easy and tasty dinner ideas. This is perfect! I had really large chicken breasts, so I only had to use one (there is only two of us). I pounded it thin and cut into two smaller breast shapes. I had italian breadcrumbs on hand and already minced garlic in the jar. I used about three tsp. of garlic (since we love it) and warmed it with butter as suggested by other viewers. I didn't have any parm but I had shredded romano so I used that instead. Since it was so thin it only needed to cook for 10 minutes on each side. Served with pasta, spaghetti sauce and garlic bread. Prep and cook time was only 30 minutes! This is def going to be on my rotation.

Effortless and very tasty. Instead of olive oil I used 2 tablespoons of butter as another reviewer suggested. This was not greasy at all..read some complaints in reviews. We made this with alfredo sauce and pasta but I REALLY think it would be much better with a tomato based sauce. This chicken would be fabulous for a chicken parmesan dish (or chicken spaghetti)...just top with grated mozzerella/parmesan. We will definitley make this again but with a tomato sauce.It was so easy and allowed plenty of time for clean up while it was baking. I love that!!!!=)Thanx

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this numerous, numerous times since May.  At times I've cooked it 10-15" longer than needed but it's never been dry:  The thick chicken breasts are always moist with a light, crisp coating (have never had a burnt crust).  I especially like that it goes well with rice, pasta, and potatoes.  (I don't think my husband notices how often I prepare Garlic Chicken because the starch & veggie side dishes are always changing!)  It's a terrific throw-together dish:  No muss no fuss.  I no longer soak/warm the olive oil & garlic.  I add extra chopped garlic, and only a little parmesian a top the breadcrumb coated breasts prior to placing in oven.  Then I add a lot more parmesian 15 minutes before removing from oven.

I knew over 1700 people couldn't be wrong. And they weren't! I'm a complete fitness/workout aholic and stick strictly to a "clean eating" diet/lifestyle. Breadcrumbs and cheese are not allowed..However.. I can have one cheat meal a week and this week I happened upon Carol's Garlic Chicken. t's got everything going for it. Easy to prepare, easy and quick to cook, will not ruin your diet and it's absolutely delish. I sliced the chicken breasts in half, to reduce the thickness.. Used slightly more garlic than the recipe calls for,added oregano to the plain breadcrumbs I was using. Warmed the garlic and oil, then marinated the chicken in it until I was ready to start cooking. Perhaps an hour or so.. Into the breadcrumb/cheese mix, into the baking dish and into the oven. It came out perfectly... moist,subtle garlic taste absolutely delish...I eat fish 5 evenings a week and I'm always looking for chicken recipes to enjoy on my chicken evenings.This one has shot straight to the top of my list...Thanks, Carol : )
Review:

5

text:
I love this recipe!  It's easy and good. I make it once a week and even my 2 year old likes it. I make it to the letter with one small exception. I crush one large clove of garlic with the broad side of a large knife using the palm of my hand instead of measuring out two teaspoons. The skin of the garlic peels away easily -- very easy and effective. Tonight I will try it with half butter/half olive oil based on a recent review I read. I'll post the results.

None
text:
Excellent! Destined to become part of our dinner rotation! The only thing I had to change were the bread crumbs. I didn't have any on hand so I just put a few scoops of Earth Grains Shredded Herb stuffing in a ziploc baggy and ran over it a few times with the rolling pin smashing the dried stuffing and viola! bread crumbs! I think this made the dish a little saltier than it would have normally been, but that was my doing, and besides it didn't change the flavor that much. I also only did three pieces of chicken and ended up using 1/2 cup of bread crumbs and 1/2 cup of P.cheese and had no breading left over. It was a huge hit served with pasta smothered in alfredo sauce and a salad of mixed greens. Thank you! Thank you! Thank you!

SOOO good and SOOO easy!! The second time making it, I did use a little extra  garlic, turned the chicken 1/2 way through cooking and after removing chicken from baking dish, I poured about 1/2 c. chicken broth (with a tsp. olive oil and some parsley added) into pan to loosen up and get the flavor from the breadcrumbs left and then poured slightly over chicken. All six of us preferred the chicken with that little added moistness.

text:
Relative to the amount of work involved, this is an awesome recipe. My prep time was maybe 20 minutes - for the chicken, the steamed brocolli I served with it, and all the veggies I cut up for a salad. I used half a head of garlic (put it thru the food processor), marinated the chicken for about an hour, and seasoned them on both sides with salt, pepper, and cajun seasoning. I used real fresh parmesan and it was fine. It wasn't the most exciting recipe, but it was good and so easy.

This was simple and quick.  It was moist, tender and absolutely delicious!  It smells so good while it is cooking.  My boyfriend was skeptical at first because I was using him as a guinea pig since I had never made this before.  He loved it and went back for seconds. Thanks for the recipe...I will use again and again for the simplicity.

text:
This was very good and easy too!  We couldn't taste the garlic (I used the minced garlic in the little glass jar from the store) but we loved the chicken anyway.  I'm a garlic fan and use that garlic all the time with good results, maybe it's because it was the bottom of the jar.  Who knows, next time I'll either use fresh garlic or I'll crush it a little with a fork to release the flavor.  Maybe I just didn't heat the mixture long enough.  Loved the recipe anyway and will definetly be making it again...garlic flavor will only add a star to an already awesome recipe!  Thanks Carol! BTW--I was going to give it 4 stars due to the garlic thing, but my VERY finicky 22 yo ate with us and said, "Hey Momma, I forgot you could cook so good." That was the 5th star for me!!  If I get it right next time and taste the garlic--It will be a 6 star recipe at my house.

text:
Delicious and very easy to make. I followed the advice of other reviewers and added just a little more garlic.  I heated up the garlic and oil in the microwave and poured it into a ziplock bag which I used to marinate the chicken in.  The only reason why I chose to marinate it overnight was so I wouldn't have to do any preparation the following day.

I used 6 chicken thighs (its what I had on hand) and it was so... good.  There was just enough bread crumbs/parmesan to cover all 6.

Will definitely make this recipe again.

text:
This has got to be the best chicken I made in a long time! I used fresh grated Parmesan cheese, seasoned bread crumbs and the garlic that comes in a jar already chopped (rather than fresh).  I pounded the chicken to flatten it out and after I made it up, I put it in the fridge for about an hour.  I bet that let the garlic flavor get into the chicken a little bit more than if I had just made it up and cooked it.  This is a "must try" if you haven't already!

This was a very good recipe, I will definately replace my other chicken recipes for this.  One suggestion that I'm going to try next time is the make your chicken into thinner pieces by either using a mallet or buying them that way.  Mine were real thick and I think they would be even better in thin pieces!!  You must try this recipe!

region:

country:
None
text:
Very easy, basic recipe and is the kind of dish that would please most.  I doubled the garlic because to me, there is no such thing as too much garlic.  I agree that infusing the olive oil with garlic is what makes this recipe differ from others.  I seasoned the chicken with salt, pepper, oregano, and basil.  I also used Italian flavored breadcrumbs rather than plain.  I think that this recipe (as written) would be very bland as it was close to being so even with my additions, but it's an easy enough recipe to doctor up to your own liking.  I served mine with marinara and it tasted like chicken parmesan.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow - this was a big hit, even with the hard to please kids.  I took alot of ideas from previous reviews...namely, pounding the chicken breasts so they are thinner, marinating them in the olive oil & garlic for about an hour, adding seasonings (black pepper, italian seasoning & some Mrs. Dash), plus flipping them halfway through the cooking time.  I also crushed up some croutons that I had in the cupboard & used those for some of the breadcrumbs, just to add some more flavour.  I ran out of the bread crumb mixture, but the breasts were big that I used.  This is a keeper!  Thanks, Carol

text:
I made this last week for dinner for my husband and I.  We both agree that we would actually like to give this recipe 3.5 stars.  This was a very good, not great, chicken dish.  It was real easy to make, which I certainly appreciated.  I used 1 1/2 teaspoons of minced garlic, rather than the crushed garlic, and I drizzled the leftover oil and bread crumb mixtures over the chicken after I'd placed it in the pan, as some others have suggested to do.  Smelled great while it was cooking, and tasted good, too.  I will be making this again sometime.

text:
I used chicken thigh instead of chicken breast and baked for 5 minutes less.  Before warming up the olive oil, I soaked the garlic in it for a good hour or so to make sure the flavors blend.  

Husband, who's a garlic hater, commented on the strong garlic smell in the kitchen before dinner with a grimace on his face but did not complain at all when he tasted it.

One thing I didn't like about it was how greasy it looked when I took it out of the baking dish.  I had to let the oil drip off a bit before putting it on a plate (see photo).

text:

After reading the reviews, I decided to season the chicken with some salt and pepper before dipping into the olive oil/garlic blend. I followed the rest of the directions. It turned out very tender and full of flavor. My family loved it.

text:
I thought this was pretty fantastic, I added alot more garlic (like 4-5 fresh cloves) and also used the parmesan cheese in the can b/c I wasn't sure which the recipe called for and thought the canned might adhere better. It did stick pretty well. I also seasoned my bread crumbs with Italian seasoning and drizzled a bit of oil onto the top before popping it in the oven. Next time I would make a bit more of the olive oil  mixture because I barely had enough. Was DEE LISH & EASY!

text:
Super-easy and very good. I wouldn't necessarily make this as a company dish, but for a quick evening meal, you can't beat this dish.

Here are my changes and recommendations:
1) I doubled the Parmesan cheese and bread crumbs. I also used Italian seasoned bread crumbs.
2) In the topping I also added a lot of spices - cayenne pepper, chili pepper, basil, etc. Just play around and add whatever suits your fancy. Have fun w/ spices.
3) The next time I make I will marinate the breasts in a light Italian dressing to make them even juicier.

This is a great recipe for an easy weekday night dinner. I served w/ broccoli rice, bagged Caesar salad and rolls.

I can't believe how easy and delicious this was. I used boneless, skinless chicken tenders because I like how much faster they cook. These came out like restaurant style fried chicken fingers. I must have made more than 10, but the family gobbled them up and wanted more. My husband LOVED them and he is just a picky as my 2 year old who also ate every last piece I gave him. This is a tasty entree. I do suggest, however, that the baking time is far too 
conservative. Unless my new oven was way off, more than 60 minutes seems
a better cooking time.

I've baked chicken in paper bags since college and never found 35 minutes long
enough to cook chicken. (I don't live in the montains where altitude could be a 
factor.)

Recommended by a chicken lover...or one who loves chicken.

userID:
615195
Display Name:
Aspiring Chef Rita
isPro:
False
followersCount:
52
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
744
favoritesCount:
1699
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/146.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this once before and gave it a 3 star rating. Even though my company liked it I told all of you that I felt I had overbreaded it, lacked garlic flavor and was dry.  I tried it again today and now give it 5 stars. - I followed the recipe exactly last time - this time I made changes.  Like others, for 4 chicken breasts I ended up doubling EVERYTHING! After preparing the oil and garlic, I poured it in a baggie along with the chicken and marinated in the frige for 2 hours (less or more time will improve the taste).  So as not to overbread the chicken, I used the shake and bake method and put the seasoned breadcrumbs and cheese in another bag and shook the chicken a piece at a time, shaking off the excess.  I also cooked it less, 425 degrees for 25 min.  It was outrageous!!!! The chicken was moist, infused with garlic flavor, you could taste the moistness of the parmesean cheese and the house smelled scrumptious!  I served it with Fettucine Alfredo, cranberry sauce and a salad with Italian dressing.  I plan to make it again next week and serve it with spaghetti w/red sauce,a salad and Italian bread.  A definite keeper - glad I tried it again.

text:
One of the best baked chicken recipes!!!  I like this recipe better with the following changes:  substitute 1/2 the oil with butter.  Add a heaping tablespoon of dijon mustard to the butter/garlic mixture before dipping in the bread crumbs/cheese.  Bake on a rack in a pan to keep it crispier.

country:
None
text:
I've made this three times and I think to get the most from it you need to take the advice of some of the other reviewers. Double crumbs, cheese and garlic. Use Italian flavored crumbs - too bland with plain crumbs. Add a few grinds of pepper to the oil. My contribution: chop the garlic and also add some chopped onion to the oil. Then strain before dipping chicken. Also 425 degrees is a bit excessive. 350 works fine for me.

text:
Made this for my family of 5 with a package of chicken tenderloins. I probably doubled the garlic and used double the butter instead of oil. I also added garlic salt, pepper and parsley to Italian seasoned bread crumbs. I drizzled the leftover butter/garlic mix over the chicken and added another thin layer of shredded Parmesan. I baked for 15 minutes at 425 degrees and then 5 more minutes at 475 to get a little more crisp. Next time Iâll try 500 degrees. Came out juicy and delicious.

text:
Easy, fast, flavorful!  Plan on making again.  We did like another reviewer.  I doubled the bread crumb and parmesan amounts, crushed about 6-7 medium to large cloves of garlic and doubled the amount of oil.   This was all used with 6 decent sized chicken breasts.  The chicken makes a difference in texture.  I had 2 breasts which had been frozen for a couple of months and I purchased 3 organics fresh breasts.  The fresh breasts were excellent.  Clean biting, juicy, etc.  The frozen breasts were also good, but more stringy and less juicy.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent! Used 4 chicken breasts.  Used about 3/4 cups italian bread crumbs and  approx 3/8 cup cheese.  Used roasted garlic infused olive oil to save time.  Put the bread crumb/cheese mix in a large zip bag and added some pepper and italian herb mix.  Dipped the chicken breast in the olive oil and then put in the bag w/bread crumb mix and tossed.  Lightly coated pan w/plain olive oil before putting in oven.  Done in 25 minutes.  Was very tender.

This was so good! These are the best chicken breasts I've had. I did marinate first for about 4ish hours. Since marinade should have a bit of acid, I added rice wine vinegar because it's mild. (For the record, had doubled the recipe for 6 pieces of chicken, all the same with 1/4C rice wine vinegar to 1/2C olive oil & the garlic for marinade). Also, used real Parmesan. Didn't have an issue, maybe because of having a full pan of chicken? Came out perfectly, thanks for the recipe

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/393834.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use boneless breasts cut in half crosswise.  I soak them in low fat buttermilk for 1/2 hour then dredge them in the parmesan and breadcrumb mixture..it sticks very well.  I melt the butter and oil with the finely minced garlic and pour it into the baking dish and dip the top of the coated breasts in the mixture and turn it garlic-oil side up..  Cover with foil for 20 minutes, remove foil and let it crisp.  Fantastic.. the buttermilk tenderizes the chicken and the coating clings well.  The flavor is excellent whatever method you use..the flavors go together so well.

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5044177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken was delicious! After dipping in oil and then crumb/cheese mixture, I let the chicken sit for 10 minutes (advice from Chef John) and then dipped in crumb/cheese mixture again resulting in a perfect crust. The garlic flavor was subtle and the parmesan flavor was wonderful. Next time I will add about 1/2 tsp of black pepper to the bread crumbs. This chicken would go great with potatoes, on salads, with pasta and many other things.

text:
No changes needed and that is a rarity for me to say. I took a picture before it went in the oven and really planned on taking another one once cooked. However, it was too good and disappeared so fast that I never got a chance to take a pic. Awesome recipe and the moistest chicken breast I have ever had. They are hard to get very juicy but this recipe did it. Perfect cook time for 6 pieces for 32 minutes in convection oven. Thank you very much for sharing!
ps: to other cooks - please use freshly grated parmesan cheese, not the bottled, dry stuff!

region:

country:
None
text:
A 5 for ease and taste.
I do not transfer oil/garlic from frying pan, just have to be on low so does not start cooking chicken breasts. Sometimes will use fork to puncture holes in breasts prior to doing anything else. 
Always add additional seasonings in with bread crumbs and parmesan (shredded better than grated). Normally some pepper and Italian seasoning .
Have heard, but not tried, is add a package of instant mashed potato flakes with bread crumbs to make even crisper.
The other nice thing about this dish, it's things already have in pantry/fridge
Don't use chicken tenders, cook to fast.

text:
This is a great recipe but I didn't cook it in the oven.  I made it in my air fryer.  I only used half of the oil the recipe called for.  I preheated my air fryer to 425 degrees and then  baked it for 10 minutes on one side; flipped it over and baked it 5 minutes on the other side.  It was so very juicy and moist and my kitchen didn't get hot at all.

text:
I loved this recipe, I use it all the time although I did make one change and it made a huge difference. I paneed the chicken so that it would be more flavorful and it helped a lot. I also used 6 pieces of chicken breasts and I still had enough breading to make more, even when the chicken was paneed. One other tip would be to pair this dish with mashed potatoes. They pair each other  very well. To summarize, this is an amazing dish on its own, but it is a lot better with a few minor tweaks.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3882726.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty!  After reading some reviews I made some minor changes to the recipe.  After making garlic oil I let it sit for 30min prior to mixing it in a bag with the tenderized chicken breasts.  I marinated the chicken for 4 hours in the garlic oil.  I mixed 1/2 panko and 1/2 Italian bread crumbs and add onion powder, pepper, and seasoned salt.  I also made the gravy one of the reviewers listed by adding about 3 Tbsp butter to the pan prior to baking.  I collected the pan drippings and added 1 Tbsp cornstarch, 1/4 c water, and 1/4 cup milk then cooked it till thickened and added Parmesan cheese.  The gravy was plain and needs some spices.  Maybe next time I'll add some rosemary and pepper to the gravy.

text:
Delicious. Will definitely make again.

My tweaks: I used boneless chicken thighs instead of chicken breasts (I eat full-fat dishes, and my cholesterol is outstanding). With almost 2 lbs of chicken, however, I had to make two batches of the coating. The recipe provided plenty of the olive oil/garlic mixture for that amount of meat. With the small amount of leftover oil, I drizzled on top of the chicken before putting it in the oven. I also used Kroger's Private Selection Parmesan & Herb Panko Bread Crumbs. I was a little worried about too much Parmesan, but it was excellent. I guess you can't have too much Parmesan. :-)

text:
I don't rate many recipes since I usually only use them as a base, but other than adding a LOT more fresh garlic, I made this mostly as written and it was a quick and easy flavorful dinner! I added onion powder, parsley, black pepper and garlic salt to the coating since I only had plain crumbs. I pounded the chicken out so the breasts would cook more evenly, and they hit 165 at 20 minutes. They didn't brown as much as I would have hoped, but the meat was VERY moist, which was a pleasant surprise! I'll save this one for sure!

text:
super easy to make! I have even made a simpler way to make it. 

note: you're going to use more bread crumbs, olive oil, parmesan, and garlic than the recipe gives.

i always pound the chicken to nake it nore tender. Next I get a microwave bowl put the olive oil in it and instead of fresh garlic I just powdered garlic and I put it in the microwave for a 30 seconds. the rest of the recipe is the same. 

My way if cheating this recipe has never proved wrong. my family didn't even notice the difference and neither did I.

text:
I made this exactly as written and thought it had zero flavor. Luckily I had made some Alfredo sauce to poor on it to try to save it. I felt like it needed some kind of additional seasoning...salt, pepper, garlic powder. It just needed something. Or maybe next time I would try it with butter or (as another reviewer suggested) Italian dressing instead of the olive oil. I also couldn't taste the garlic at all and I had put in extra. If a recipe needs certain seasonings that should be listed as part of the ingredients as I always try to make a recipe as written so I can give an honest review. Also I think the cooking time is too long as my chicken came out a little dry.

Very yummy! I did what another reviewer did, and I dipped my chicken in a beaten egg, then into the bread crumb/freshly grated parmesan mixture; placed into 9X13 baking dish, and poured the olive oil/garlic on top of the chicken. Made with mashed potatoes and a strawberry and spinach salad. 5 thumbs up! Thanks for this recipe!

text:
Easy and Excellent. I did increase the garlic and used butter instead of olive oil and  corn flake crumbs in place of bread crumbs. Against the advice of another I used chicken tenderloins (that's all I had). However, I did reduce cooking time to 20 mins and reduced temp to 350. Only problem I had was the breading came off the bottom. Just scraped it out of the baking dish and put back on top.  Not sure how to correct that. Definitely will make again.

Display Name:
kronic22

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this dish for many years now, before I saw the recipe here.

I use low fat/ non-fat italian dressing in place of the oil.  I add some red chilli flakes, garlic powder, and crushed black pepper to the breading mix, but I like things a little spicy.  Also, let the coated/breaded chicken rest in the fridge for 30 minutes, I feel like it helps the breading 'stick' better....but that just might be in my head.

I top the finished baked chicken with italian cheese blend and marinara sauce and bake for another ten minutes...kinda like chicken parm.  I love mushrooms, so I throw some sauteed mushrooms and onions on top before serving.  Never have leftovers.

Sorry that this isn't really a review of the recipe, hope I didn't offend the recipe author,  just thought I'd share.

text:
After reading the reviews, I added these changes.  I had 5 pieces of chicken drump sticks so used 1/3 cup bread crumbs, 1/4 c. parmesan cheese, and 1 tsp of Italian seasoning to the bread crumbs, since I didn't have Italian bread crumbs.  I used 4 cloves garlic, and let the oil and garlic sit awhile in a bag with the chicken.
My husband loved it.  I baked it on 350 for 55 min.  I should of had the heat higher maybe 375 as that's what I usually set my temp on for making chicken, but had a new oven so still trying to figure it out.  I for sure would make this again.

text:
I followed someone else's recommendation of substituting italian dressing for the olive oil & garlic.  It made this recipe so much easier because there wasn't any prep cooking, just dip in the dressing, then into the breadcrumb mixture, then cook it.  My supermarket sells very large and thick chicken breasts in packs of 5, so I wound up butterflying the breasts & splitting them between me & hubby.  This recipe turned into 10 servings when served with 2 sides.

text:
I thought this recipe was very tasty! I cut my chicken breasts in half and ended up using twice the amount of the Parmesan (from a green Kraft container)/seasoned Panko breadcrumb mixture. I ended up cooking the breasts for maybe 15-20 minutes over the recommended amount (so around 50-55 minutes total) because the breasts were fairly thick, and I am always concerned about underdone chicken. They were flavorful but not overwhelmingly so and had a nice texture.

text:
Instead of just dunking the chicken in the garlic and oil, breaking it, and then cook the chicken I decided to pour the oil and garlic all of the chicken after it was breaded and placed in the baking dish. I also added about maybe another 1/2 of Parmesan over the chicken breasts and added salt and pepper. The garlic bits cooked very nicely, turning crispy and provided a great crunch element to the buttery chicken. Overall a great recipe, my family loved it!

text:
I am not sure about this recipe.  As with all new recipes I followed it to the letter, because I think that it is better to try it out before tweaking it.  However, I am not sure if I will make this again.  The chicken I used turned out quite dry and chewy and the flavour of the parmesan cheese seemed to overpower the taste of the chicken.   Even so, I liked the idea of coating it in garlic oil and then seasoned breadcrumbs, so if I do it again I will omit the cheese and then bake it for slightly less time to prevent it from being dry.

userID:
3382786
Display Name:
Christina
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
104
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The chicken was very moist and tender and tasted great with some additional seasonings. I added red pepper flakes and rosemary to the garlic/oil. I marinated the chicken in a plastic bag with the oil for about an hour. I added Italian seasoning, onion powder, garlic powder, seasoned salt, and pepper to the crumbs/parm. I only made 2 breasts, but needed more than 1/4 cup bread crumbs and 1/4 cup parm cheese. The temp seemed too high, so I baked them at 375 for 20-25 min (I used thin breasts) and put under the broiler for 5 min to brown the crumbs.

5

text:
I really love this recipe, it's simple, quick, uses stuff I have on hand, and is really tasty. I recommend pounding out the thickest part of the chicken breast to start out so it's an even thickness (it bakes more evenly). I did this this the first time exactly as written, and the second time used pork chops instead of chicken, and added a sprinkle of sage and some black pepper.  Either way, it's a definite keeper.

text:
I truly had high hopes for this.  Things I liked about it were that my 9 year old granddaughter was able to help me make it, and that was lovely. She was able to squeeze the limes and combine all the spices which was a fabulous, natural lesson in fractions.   I also liked it that our granddaughter who likes just plain meat really enjoyed this.  On the other hand, I thought the recipe was just short of tasteless.  We made the recipe nearly as stated except we used fresh thyme instead of dried and we cut up the chicken into bite-sized pieces in the hope that the flavoring permeated the meat better.  We served it over brown rice and spooned the sauce from the pan over it.  That, for me, was the good part as the sauce was very tasty.

country:

text:
First review. I was looking for a quick and easy way to cook some chicken without leaving the house. At first glance I thought this recipe was weak, but after seeing all the reviews, I figured what the heck. No dice. Soggy bottom crums, marginally moist chicken and a grumpy wife. 

The proper way to cook this dish would be to add salt and pepper to the chicken, dredge in flour, dip in egg wash, dip in bread crumb and cheese mixture, pan fry each side to brown and stick in the oven to finish.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken is surprisingly moist and flavorful. I did make a few changes from the suggestions of other reviewers to the recipe mainly I added more garlic (more than 2 tablespoons for two thick pieces of chicken) and I let the chicken marinate in the olive oil garlic mixture for about 30 minutes. I also added some fresh grated parmesan cheese to the top of the chicken for the last 5 minutes and flipped it half way through the cooking. I would reccomend keeping an eye on the chicken because 30-35 minutes may be too much time (I cooked my chicken for 35 minutes but the breasts were very thick).

Display Name:
Tonya Alexander
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2731561.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best baked/fried chicken recipe I have ever found! I am a Lo-carb dieter so I made my bread crumbs fresh from Lo-carb white bread (6 carbs per slice).  I mixed the Parmesan in the bread crumb along with a dash of sea salt & ground pepper. I used Tyson frozen (& thawed) boneless breast tenders rather than the boneless breast. I dipped them in the olive oil & crushed garlic then into the bread crumbs & parmesan.  I placed the breaded tenders onto a cookie sheet that I had brushed with olive oil. I then turned them half way through the baking process in order to get them nice and crunchy baked on both sides. I can eat this dish without the guilt since I made the bread crumbs fresh with lo-carb bread slices. And the good thing is...my family loved them and didn't even realize that they were eating healthy fried chicken!

text:
This was DELICIOUS!! So simple to make and a crowd pleaser to boot! The chicken was so tender and juicy, which blew my mind as I always tend to dry out chicken breasts when I bake them. The only (and I mean ONLY) changes I made to this (I just couldn't help myself- I always make changes) was to add a little bit of Italian seasoning and garlic powder to the bread crumb/cheese mixture. I would've used Italian bread crumbs but I didn't have any on hand... I served these with garlic mashed potatoes, and while we all had garlic breath for the rest of the night, man was it worth it.

This was definitely easy, but it was mediocre compared to the rock star reviews. I thought the garlic-olive oil coating was gona knock my my socks off but it was just average. maybe next time I'll use 2 cloves instead of just one.  i precoated the chicken in flour and also added onion powder, season salt & pepper to the italian breadcrumb mixture. We will most likely try this again for an easy dish, but will tweak it for a just a liiiittle bit more garlic flavor! I'm going to research the reviews & get some helpful hints.
Review:

5

Just made this recipe tonight for
the first time- and my family and I loved it! I used thin
chicken breasts. I followed the recipe exactly just seasoned the chicken before after dipping in the olive oil/garlic mixture w/black pepper and onion powder then proceeded to press the chicken into Italian planko crumbs
and parmesan/Romano grated cheese mixture.  It
was light & delicious!  Next time I'll blend the olive oil and garlic together and then let the chicken sit in it for 30 mins to see if it tastes moister and even better. Delicious!!

DISCOBUNNY

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/65375.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken was juicy, tender and delicious! Because I'm lazy, I poured the warmed olive oil and garlic into a baggie with the chicken breasts and just mooshed it around, then used a second baggie for shaking the pieces in the dry mixture.

I used seasoned bread crumbs, parm and granulated garlic. Because we had 5 large chicken breasts, I ended up needing more coating mixture. Just sprinkled extra of each on top of the pieces and then drizzled with a bit of olive oil. Took 35 minutes for those 5 large breasts to be cooked perfectly.

I've made similar dishes with butter and bread crumbs/crackers, but I'd never tried it with olive oil. I'm sure it would work well for pork chops, too. Very easy and very yummy!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Who knew?! We've been doing this to wild Alaskan halibut (just bake it about 10-12 min./ till it flakes with fork) for years with exceptional results. One BIG CHANGE (for chicken and fish): substitute finely crushed goldfish crackers for breadcrumbs--little kids love "helping" crush them and they impart a little extra cheesiness :-). To reduce time in the oven for chicken, either precook 5-10 min. in microwave or pan cook over medium heat about 10 min. before breading. You can't lose with this easily adaptable, delicious recipe! (If using fish, have malt vinegar on hand.)

country:

text:
I loved it. It was really good. I love garlic but am not a huge fan of parmasan so I was a bit nervous. I had a couple of very little pieces done way before others and when I tried them, I was so thrilled.
I used butter like some reviews suggested here and I put lots and lots of garlic. I also used panko bread crumbs cause that's all I had. I personally like panko better than other bread crumbs anyway.
This is definitely a keeper. Oh, the only thing that I wasn't too crazy about is the time. I had to cook mine way too long. I don't know if it's our oven or the breast size or what but after 30 minutes, my chicken was not done at all. I think I left them in for at least 45 to 50 mins which dried out a couple of smaller pieces. I think next time, I would use tenderloins rather than breasts and cut down the cooking time.

text:
Thanks for posting-this was really good!  I followed the recipe almost exactly except for the bread crumb mixture.  I had plain bread crumbs but I thought it would be a little bland with just that and Parmesan so I added in a few sprinkles of onion powder, oregano, basil, paprika and red pepper flakes to spice it up.  I baked it for 30 minutes and let it rest for the remaining 5 minutes.  The chicken came out moist and it smelled AWESOME while cooking.  Served it with mashed potatoes and some mixed veggies.  Yep - I will definitely be making this one again!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I really liked this! We've made something similar to this with egg, flour and breadcrumbs, but with the olive oil and garlic as the base then the breadcrumbs and Parmesan,this was awesome! The olive oil keeps the chicken tender and even with as much garlic as I actually added (more then recommended for 2 breasts of chicken) the garlic wasn't overpowering. I let the breadcrumbs get crispy in the oven (2 thin breasts of chicken, 30 min and the breadcrumbs crisped right up). It gave it that extra crunch. I saw that the recipe picture was served with veggies, which is probably a better idea. I served it with some linguine (just olive oil and parm mixed in, no sauce) and it was really good! My husband's Italian so I had to do the pasta! I'd definitely recommend this. Try it. It's so quick and easy.

region:

country:
None
text:
For gluten-free folks: finely crushed potato chips make a good substitute for the bread crumbs--nice and crunchy with a good flavor.  Maybe it's just me, but any recipe that calls for dredging something in crumbs really underestimates the amount needed.  Same with this one--I ended up making more of the crumb+parmesan mixture so that there would be enough.  I also mixed the garlic and oil in a zipper bag and then let the chicken marinate in that for several hours.  Very tasty!

Very easy, fairly healthy and useful for when you're rushed. In keeping with my family's taste, I used more garlic, a mix of parmesan and romano and two types of bread crumbs -- seasoned Italian and homemade from a French loaf; the addition of the latter to make it crunchier. I've been keeping my eye out for simple recipes for my daughter who just graduated college and who claims she can't cook, and this is a good one for her.

text:
Great! Quick and easy week-night dinner (just whip up a pasta side and some veggies). My boyfriend and I both loved this, the olive oil gave it a nice crunch. It's key to warm the olive oil with the garlic! I just put mine in the microwave for 30 seconds or so. For a slightly healthier alternative, whip up two eggs with a few tablespoons of milk and dip chicken in that before coating in the bread crumbs.

text:
Great recipe! Simple and easy to do. I had some infused garlic oil, so I just used that instead of making my own for this recipe. The bottom of the chicken gets a little soggy, but the top is nice and crispy. I did spray the top of the chicken with an olive oil cooking spray to help it get a bit more brown and crispy. Chicken stays moist if you don't overbake. I had cut a few breasts in half for the kids (to make strips), and they were a tad drier than the whole breasts.

text:
Made this last night and I thought it tasted great. I did read the reviews and did half salted butter half olive oil for the garlic to roast in.I also added salt to my bread crumb mixture. I also cooked it at 350 for about 30 min. One review said that cooking at 425 would be too hot and dry it out so I listened. Mine turned out SO MOIST! Almost too moist, I would rather my chicken have a crisp to the coating, I did turn temp up to 425 and cook for an addition 5 min. I would really recommend this, but you need to add salt. I will def make this again and hopefully can get the temp and time down so it will crisp up nicer next time.

text:
I modified this recipe a bit, as I'm dieting.  I minced up 7 or 8 cloves of garlic, threw it in about a cup of Ken's Steakhouse light Northern Italian Dressing and marinaded in that.  Breaded it in a mix of Italian breadcrumbs, rosemary, oregano, freshly crushed black peppercorn and salt.  OH MY WORD...The smell alone while it was cooking was mouth-watering.  I paired it with a fresh ceasar salad and it was sooo tasty! Will be making this often.  My boyfriend said it's in his top 3 favorite meals! Note: I cooked this for 35 mins on 350.  I thought the temp might be too hot, but my breading probably would have browned up and crunched up nicer in the higher temp.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is so simple, and that's what makes it amazing!

Just a few notes for myself, and others if they are in a situation similar to myself.

1) I adjusted the servings for 2 since I only had 2 skinless, boneless chicken breast halves.  However, I did butterfly the chicken breast halves and found that the suggested measurements for the cheese and bread crumbs did not cover all the chicken, so if you are in a similar situation it may help to stick with the same amount of bread/cheese as measured by the original recipe.

2) I used garlic powder instead of cloves, simply because this was last minute and I did not have cloves! Still tasted awesome!

3) I cooked it at 350 for ~30 minutes instead of 425 because I thought that would be too hot, however I now realize the chicken would have been more crispy at 425.  Next time I will test it and bake at the recommended 425 mark.

Thanks Carol!

text:
This is a great, easy recipe. I make it often. The oil keeps the chicken moist and tender. If you don't like garlic, you can leave it out and it's still delicious. I sometimes cut the chicken in strips and do it the same way--it bakes faster. I also sometimes top with pasta sauce from a jar and mozzarella toward the end of baking time for easy chicken parmesan.

country:
None
text:
We liked it very much and will make again.  Easy and quick.  My suggestion is to place the chicken on a rack in a rimmed baking sheet (which I didn't do, but will do next time).  That way, the chicken should be crisp on the bottom as well as the top and won't bake in its own fat.  I used panko bread crumbs which really added crunch.  I also added some chopped fresh rosemary in the garlic-olive oil infusion and the bread crumb-parmesean coating.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic base recipe.  However after reading previous comments I decided to make a few adjustments.  I used 8 cloves of crushed garlic, put them into about 1/3 of a cup of olive oil.  Took that to a boil and took it off the heat to cool down.  I put salt, pepper and powdered garlic on both sides of the chicken and then placed into the olive oil mixture.  The only adjustments I made to the bread crumb mixture was to season the bread crumbs with pepper and powdered garlic and I used extra parm cheese.  Also I cook my chicken breasts at 375 for 30 minutes they are always juicy yet cooked through.  My kids and husband loved it!!!

I was astonished at how tasty and juicy these chicken breasts turned out! This recipe is super easy and super tasty. I was concerned over some of the lower ratings on taste, but I followed the recipe as is for flavor and it really pulled through. I did reduce the oven temperature to 400 instead of 425 based on some reviews, so these were perfect. I served them to my husband who doesn't really care too much for chicken breasts (he prefers dark meat) and even he was amazed. I served this with mashed potatoes one time and the second time with rosemary & garlic roasted potatoes & broccolini, which went very well together.

text:
Tasty! I used chicken thighs.  Based on others' comments, I did a blend of butter & oil & added extra spices (italian seasoning, paprika, cayenne, parsley & chicken seasoning).  I didn't have bread crumbs so I used instant mashed potato flakes.  I didn't have canned parmesan cheese so I grated fresh.  It turned out tasty, although it wasn't crisp.  I put foil over the dish until the last 5 minutes of baking.  Next time I will try it without foil, and use bread crumbs & canned parmesan cheese.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an incredibly simple, tasty recipe that has become an almost weekly addition to our meal rotation.  I have three young kids who are somewhat finicky about their food, and they all love it.  The only thing I do differently is up the amount of garlic by...well, I don't really know.  Probably triple.  I love garlic :).  Other people have commented on the lovely smell while baking, and I agree wholeheartedly.  Warming the garlic in the olive oil is a very important step that starts the aroma-producing effect.

I've also used the same exact recipe to prepare tilapia filets.  The recipe, at least to me, is even better with fish.  Just follow the same exact steps as with the chicken, and use a probe thermometer to monitor the temperature of the fish to avoid over-cooking.  Bake the tilapia to 140 degrees, and enjoy.

This was so easy! I did change it up a bit per previous reviews.  I used melted butter instead of oil and used the same quantities even though I only had 2 chicken breasts instead of 4. I also added some parsley, oregano, paprika, salt and pepper to the breadcrumb mixture, and used freshly shredded parmesan cheese. I baked it for the recommended time and the chicken was perfectly cooked, with such a tasty breadcrumb/parmesan crust, and so moist!!!

This is going to become one of our weeknight staples, I'm sure.

text:
Great recipe!  I used a peach vinigrette, instead of just olive oil, with the garlic.  I didn't have any bread crumbs on hand, so I crushed some seasoned crutons.  I didn't follow the measurements exactly may have gotten a bit carried away with the garlic.  I also added the remaining dressing/garlic mixture to the pan and sprinked the remaining bread crumbs over the chicken before adding the parmesean (I couldn't bring myself to toss the remaining mixture).  While it wasn't as crunchy as it could have been, it was still quite delish.  The peach vinigrette added a subtle fruity touch.  Will definitely make this recipe again.

region:

country:
None
text:
Made this for dinner tonight. I had 3 chicken breast that I defatted, split & pounded. Doubled the garlic & oil and marinated for an hour. I tripled the breading and used a combo of panko & bread crumbs. Added pepper and Italian seasonings to the bread crumbs. Glad that I made a lot of bread crumbs since it was the perfect amount. Baking time was 15-20 mins. When the chicken was done, I sprinkled shredded cheddar cheese and put it back in the warm oven to melt. The chicken was nice, crunchy & not dried out. Ate it with rice. Would be great with spaghetti. Thanks!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish is so simple and amazing! I had to put in overtime tonight, and got home at 4AM absolutely STARVING with no food except a frozen chicken breast. As I defrosted it in the microwave, I went looking for a fast, easy recipe and found this one!  Even though I only had one chicken breast, I kept the oil and garlic amounts the same, poured half into a dish for "dredging" the chicken, and then used the rest for my sides - added some to the water for couscous, and sauteed some broccoli and bok choy in some of the oil with red chili flakes. I also used panko bread crumbs for the chicken, and made sure to really pack it on! 32 minutes in the oven, and the chicken came out PERFECT - very moist and juicy, with a very crunchy outer layer, and wonderfully tasty! This will likely become my go-to recipe when I don't know what to cook!  I like to bento for my lunches and such when I can - maybe I'll try this recipe on some chicken tenders for that and see how it goes!
Review:

5

Wow, what a simple, fantastic recipe! text:
I've made this several times now and we love this. First we season the chicken breast with Morton's Nature's Seasoning.  Then we used plain bread crumbs and added black pepper, onion powder, garlic powder, paprika and lots of parmesan cheese. Baked at 375 for about 40-50 minutes.  The chicken breast came out juicy and tender.  This is our go to comfort food...complete with a side of veggies and mac and cheese.

text:
This is a 5 star keeper.  I am a dark meat person and cringe when I have to made breasts/white meat, but its what we had - I'm so glad I found this! Moist and yummy, even for those that prefer dark meat.  Other reviews said to make sure to use the green can parmesan .... but I prefer to shred my own - it stuck just fine and worked beautifully.  I used 2 big breasts, each cut in half, and didn't have quite enough dry mixture for all - so next time I'll increase freshly grated  parm/crumb mix to 1/3 cup each.  Other than that, just perfect.  Thanks for posting!!

text:
This recipe is so excellent!! I hate chicken breast, but they were deeelicious with this coating!! So moist and flavorful.  My husband constantly asks me when we can have it for dinner again! I like it more on thighs and dark meat, but this way I can also have the healthier white meat.  You must make this, especially if you like garlic.  Be sure to use fresh garlic and use 2 teaspoons, which will be several (5-7) of garlic as another person said. YUMMMMMMMMMY!

text:
It was good but I'd like more flavour.  I even use the Italian seasoned breadcrumbs. I  will definitely add more Parmesan up to a cup  next time.   Warm the garlic & olive oil in the microwave for 1 minute or until you can smell the garlic.  It infuses its flavour to the oil.  I flattened the chicken breast  to 3/4 of an inch and baked it for 22 minutes.  The chicken came out really moist.  I'll update next time  with upped parmesan.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/188654.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very good recipe.  In my opinion, it was not bland at all.  First, I used both chicken breasts and thighs to give options between white/dark meat. Then, I seasoned all the chicken with adobo, fresh ground pepper, and a little bit of Webber's garlic seasoning.  Instead of oil I used butter and upped the garlic to about 3 teaspoons for every 4 chicken breasts.  I began cooking at 400 degrees however, the breadcrumbs on the bottom of the pan started burning so I lowered the temp to 350 and cooked for about 35 minutes.  So delicious - use seasoned breadcrumbs!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic... tweaked, of course.  A friend recommended this recipe and frankly I'm a little tired of breaded and baked chicken .  However, this was perfect without the breading.  I use about twice the amount of garlic (chopped, not pressed), dip the chicken in the oil/garlic mix and coat it in pecorino romano.  Towards the very end of baking, I cover the chicken in roughly chopped marinated artichoke hearts.  I serve it on homemade fettucini and there is never any left at the end of the meal.

country:
None
text:
The chicken turned out very yummy.  I would only make one adjustment to make this a 5-star recipe.  I would either pound the chicken before cooking it in order to make it more tender or slice each chicken breast half into two thinner pieces (but then you would need to adjust cooking time).  The problem I encountered with using just a chicken breast half is that it was way too thick and the flavor didn't get all the way through to the center.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We absolutely loved this recipe!!  My boyfriend and I wanted to make a quick and easy dinner with ingredients already on hand.  We cut the chicken into chunks instead of just using 2 whole chicken breasts.  We cut down on the olive oil a little bit and mixed it with melted margarine.  We warmed some minced garlic in the metled margarine/olive oil then dipped the chicken chunks into the mixture.  After coating the chicken well we dipped it into the breadcrumb/cheese/spices mixture.  We baked covered for 30 mins, then uncovered for 10 mins.  The chicken came out moist and juicy and the coating got a little crisp.  It was absolutely wonderful!!!  I will definitely be making this again

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/228114.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you're a working wife and mother, then this recipe is a fast week day meal that you'll love for it's versatility.  It's so simple, I warmed the oil and garlic in the microwave, ran the shredded parm cheese that I had thru the food processor so that it had more of a crumb like texture which made it mix w/ the breadcrumbs beautifully.  I dipped and coated the chicken as instructed in the recipe and baked on a parchment lined cookie sheet for about 20 minutes for 5 small boneless skinless breasts and dinner was done.  I served with sauted shallots and peas which I prepared while the chicken was baking.  I can't wait to try this again, but I'm going to turn this quick and easy meal into parmesan chicken.  I'm also going to try pounding the chicken breasts thin and then when done serve to the kiddos as chicken strips. This is going into our regular menu rotation. Thanks so much for sharing.

I'm a nanny and always on the lookout for easy recipes. Man was this a cinch and it made me look like a gourmet cook. The baking temp seemed too hot so I consulted the back of the Tyson box and reduced the heat to 350 degrees but kept the baking time the same. After placing the chicken in the pan I sprinkled some Italian seasoning and salt and pepper to give it some more added flavor. Served with pasta and sauce and a vegetable such as broccoli, you have an instant easy weeknight meal.

This wasn't the type of meal you make to impress others at dinner parties, but it was pretty tasty for an easy and simple recipe. What I liked most was how quick it is to make, and its pretty healthy, making it a realistic meal for those who lack time during the week, and who try to eat relatively healthy. I served this with some rosemary potatoes and sauteed veggies, which all went nicely together. The chicken was extremely moist, and I will definitely make this again because it is perfect for those days when I am short on time/energy.

text:
This was soooooo good. Quick and simple and so delicious. I did use about 5 garlic cloves and also some fresh parsley in the olive oil. Make sure you don't burn the garlic! Heat the mixture for about 3min on low.I also got the butcher to pound the chicken thin, this makes it easier to cook through. I also used VIGO brand breadcrums, I'm not too sure if you can get this brand at any supermarket but I live in Miami so its always on hand. By far the best breadcrumbs, it has a bunch of spices in it that makes it extra tasty! My husband loved it, this is definitely a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Soooo good.  Very easy and tasty.  I first seasoned my chicken with a bit of garlic salt and black pepper.  I forgot to get bread crumbs from the store so I used saltine crackers, finely ground, instead.  I was a bit worried but it worked out wonderfully.  I also added more garlic to oil and just a bit more cheese.  Also, if possible turn the chicken when the top is browned so that the bottom won't be soggy. I tried this with both chicken breasts and chicken breast tenders.  Both were great.  This is a definite must-try.

I thought this was fine. I didn't have a lot of garlic flavor, and I don't know if I had marinated it a little bit in the olive oil/garlic mixture if that would have made a difference. text:
This was a great recipe, but I added a few changes. I was cooking dinner for a friend of mine who's husband is vegetarian, and this is my take on the recipe. I marinaded the chicken in the late morning for evening dinner. I also marinaded Quorn chicken style pieces but with some Tamari soy sauce, and added (to both lots) half a chopped green chili (we don't like things too hot) and freshly ground black pepper, also added freshly ground black pepper to the crumb/cheese mixture. The result was liked by all, and both my friend and hubby would eat it again. Thanks for posting.

text:
I think this is a good, quick and easy chicken to make for dinner. Sometimes I pound the chicken to make it a little thinner and more tender before dipping it in the oil. I only gave this recipe 4 stars because several times the chicken has come out a little dry, and I think it needs some kind of sauce with it. My husband and 2 year old seem to like it quite well, especially dipped in a homemade ranch dressing. I think I will try it next with a marinara sauce, or maybe on a salad. It is good on its own - don't get me wrong - I just think it could somehow be better. It's still a keeper in my recipe collection!

text:
I made this recipe for dinner tonight, and my fiance and I absolutely loved it!!!  The chicken came out wonderful, and it was tremendously moist.  First, I put a little touch of my own seasoning.  I put Italian seasoning on both sides of the chicken before I dredged it in the mixture, and I used Italian bread crumbs.  Everything else was great... parmesan gave it a wonderful flavor.  I put the roasted garlic on top of the chicken while it was baking for 30 minutes.  So easy to make... yet so delicious!  Can't beat this one... thanks for the recipe!

Great Recipe!!  Kids and adults love this and it takes no time at all to make. I do add more garlic about 1 tblsp instead of 2 teaspoons. I love the garlic flavor.  When I put the chicken breast in the baking dish i pour the remainder of the olive oil/garlic mix over the breasts and spoon some more of the bread crumb/parmesan mixture over it just for that little extra coating.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5106483.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this this since 2006. I end up scooping minced garlic from the jar (quite a bit of it) and I don't measure the oil anymore;  I make the recipe bigger often for a family pack because we love leftovers. This is a very forgiving recipe that you can flavor up to suit the mood, tonight I added Italian herbs and some pepper to the breading. Don't be shy and use that parmesan, it makes the difference. I serve it with green veggies and either brown rice or leftover pasta. Any Italian style pasta will do. I also use a thermometer probe to ensure proper cook time without over cooking the meat.

I made only a couple of changes:  I used more garlic as mentioned in other reviews and instead of bread crumbs which I was out of, I used ground up Ritz Crackers which was very good.  I also added some chili powder and seasoning salt to the bread crumb/cracker mixture.  I will definately make this again and again!

text:
I just made this and it was awesome! I read over other people's suggestions and the chicken came out really well. I used A LOT of garlic cloves and it was really good. I sprinkled some garlic powder and black pepper on the chicken before dipping it into the hot oil/garlic mix. I also added a little garlic and onion powder along with Cajun seasoning into the bread crumb (Italian seasoning)/parmesan mix. I put the chicken in for 20 mins @ 425 degrees and then sprinkled a little parm. on and broiled it for about 5 mins. Served with rice pilaf and green beans! Excellent!

text:
I flattened the chicken, made tenders and baked for 25 minutes.  I'm a garlic lover but I went way overboard on the garlic.  Two cloves minced + half teaspoon garlic powder in the bread crumb mixture for one chicken breast is way overboard.  Ha.  No matter; it was wonderful the next day in a toasted kaiser with mayonnaise, a leaf of romaine and a slice of tomato.  I also used shredded parmesan for texture and added some cracked pepper to the breading.

text:
I was thrilled at the responses I saw online to this recipe and picked it out for a very important and large dinner party.  Thank goodness I did a test-run in advance.  

I cooked it tonight - it was fair.  We LOVE garlic, and we like chicken, so I figured it'd be a home run.  It was not bad, but not one that I'd rave about and honestly not one that I'll cook again.  It did look just like the picture, which was nice.  My husband described the problem as "something missing".  I feel like it would benefit from possibly some additional spices to complement the garlic.

This was easy & excellent! I love garlic but I despise too much.  I was afraid the garlic would be too overpowering because little chunks were sticking to the chicken, but it turned out with just the right amount of garlic/cheese flavor.  I cut the cheese in half tho, to try and save on some calories. Also, as others suggested, I pounded the meat thin (so only needed need 2 breast halves) and cut the cooking time to 20 minutes.   Perfect!  This was plenty for 2 with leftovers for lunch.

text:
"MMMMMMMM mmmmmmmmmm mmmmmmmm sorry I can't talk - too busy eating"  That was a direct quote from my satisfied husband after making this surprisingly easy and DELICIOUS chicken.
For years, I have been doing the flour, egg, bread crumb chicken that is fried in oil.

This is a MILLION times better.  I pounded out the chicken and found that since you then get a larger surface area, we needed more bread crumbs and parmesan (freshly grated as always).  Also, because it's thinner when it's tenderized, it only took 20 minutes.

PHENOMENAL!

text:
I made this since it was simple and sounded good. It exceeded my expectations!! The smell of it when it cooks is wonderful. I would suggest increasing the amount of bread crumbs and parmesan and use more garlic in the oil if you really like it garlicky like I do. Let the garlic stick to the meat before breading it to give it flavor. The chicken comes out moist and brown and very flavorful. I actually crave this one now! Try it!

text:
SIMPLE RECIPE, TRY IT!! I made 3 variations to the recipe: 1) I used drumsticks with skin, 2) a ridiculous amount of garlic which i crushed in a mortor and soaked in the olive oil for a few hours, and 3) I had "italian style" bread crumbs on hand (has romano cheese in it already) which i substituted for the parmesan and bread crumbs.  It tasted crispy and as if it was fried.  Next time i will try adding chili powder to the olive oil to make it spicy.

I had one very large bs breast -- not enough for a meal for 4, but a nice add-in to another dish.  So, I cut it into good-sized chunks, dipped them in oil and crumbs/cheese, pan-fried them in more garlic oil, then added them to the Cavatelli and Broccoli recipe.  A great combination!

I am going to give this a four only because my husband who doesn't care for chicken said he loved it. I felt the coating didn't get cristy enough. I would rate it closer to a 3 or 2.5 My husband thought maybe this should be deep fried instead of baked. Anyway, I felt this was "one step above" the typical overrated canned soup recipes that I come across from this site. I think it was fine but it was not extraordinary. It certainly would be good for something like parmesan chicken etc. Served it with the "rich pasta from a poor kitchen" from this site and the flavors matched very well. I also think Italian bread crumbs should be used instead of plain. Went great with Cakebread Cellars Pinot Noir.

No vampires in my house *smile*. I used 2 tablespoons of cheese; a blend of fresh ramano/parm cheese. I was concerned about the cheese because I have two children who HATE cheese, but they did not complain. It would probably be better with the full amount of cheese, but I'll take what I can get! I think I cooked it for about 25 minutes; the chicken breasts I used must have been on the smaller side. This will DEFINATELY become a staple! Thanks Carol!

text:
Very tasty!!  Our family has a variation...try melting a stick of butter with the garlic(5 cloves), and olive oil...dip the chicken pieces into the oil mixture, then roll in crushed potato chips, mixed with some garlic powder, some seasoned salt, and some fresh ground pepper, and the parmesean cheese....the potato chips add a great texture and flavor!!!  If you like dark meat, cooking time increases 5-10 minutes.

The flavor was great. I added more garlic than the recipe called for.  The bread crumb coating could didn't firm up quite enough. The chicken cooked well and was very tender, additional cooking may have helped the coating but more than likely would have dried out the chicken. Overall, a good dish and very easy and quick to prepare.

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe. It didn't have much of a garlic taste though. I used garlic powder instead of garlic cloves. I will make it with fresh garlic next time for a stronger flavor. I used fresh grated Parmesan cheese instead of canned. It makes a big difference in flavor. I made the dish Chicken Parmesan style. At the end of the baking time, I topped the breasts with marinara sauce and mozzeralla cheese. It turned out wonderfully. I served it with spaghetti and garlic bread.
